title: campbeltown courier letters week 31
story: Sir,I wish to thank all the people of Campbeltown and especially the members of Yes Kintyre for the wonderful hospitality they gave us independence marchers on Saturday. I#ve been on many a demonstration in my time and this was one of the best.Rolling off the ferry on the Friday evening we were welcomed by a guard-of-honour standing along the pier waving saltires.The townsfolk turned out in droves to welcome us, waving saltires from windows and even stringing saltire bunting across the street at fourth-storey level. I had the romantic impression that the good folk of Campbeltown had been following the ious pro-independence rallies as they worked their way around the geography of Scotland and had just been waiting for their own town#s turn!The sun stayed out for us right until pm. Then the rain suddenly came down and we took down our Pensioners for Independence stall.  That evening Yes Kintyre put on a special party for us all with local musicians in the Argyll Arms Hotel.On Sunday some of us stayed on and explored your beautul peninsula. As the ferry pulled away that evening members of Yes Kintyre stood along the harbour wall holding up saltires to bid us farewell.Thank you all again for a memorable experience.Yours,Mary McCabe,Glasgow.Sir,It was my great privilege to attend yet another Open at Royal Portrush and to witness  year-old Oban golfer Robert MacIntyre finish tied sixth in his very first Major Championship.It was a wonderful performance, and confirmation, of the talent and the temperament we, the journalists, felt sure that he had.  He is now a Euro millionaire, but he remains an open, helpful and cheerful lad with both feet firmly planted on the ground, thanks to a great family and a strong desire to remain in his home town.I was at Glencruitten for the first time in June and soon discovered why Robert wants to go back there on a regular basis after weeks on tour.  It#s a terric club, no airs and graces.  They are very proud of Robert, and rightly so, but I very much doubtthey would allow him to lose his down-to-earth approach to international recognition.Yours,Jock MacVicar, Southend-born Scottishgolf correspondent and long-time Dunaverty member. Sir,Through the columns of your newspaper, may I express my grateful thanks to all the businesses, organisations, and iniduals, who donated to our fundraising, allowing the dancers to compete in the United States Highland Dancing Championships held recently in Las Vegas.We had a very successful trip, placing in both the Highland and choreography events. It’s installed in the dancers they are there to represent Campbeltown and the Dance School rather than any inidual, and hearing the town name announced at the presentation of trophies to our four trophy winners was a very proud moment indeed. The dancers fought every inch of the way to put our small town on the map.Our thanks once again to the following: MACC, Tangy Wind Farm, West Kintyre Wind Farm, Killieguer Caravan Park, DM Fabrication, Glenside Tractors, Howdens, Kintyre Youth Fund, McFadyens Contractors, Tesco Bags of Help, Jim Martin Supplies, Southend Parish Church, Peter McKerral  Son, C’town Co-Op, C’town Running Club, C’town Rotary Club, C’town Firemans Club, C’town Motor Co, C’town Rotary Club, C’town Loyal, C’town Common Good Fund, C’town Inner Wheel, C’town Community Council, Paul Grumoli, Mr and Mrs Brown, Mr and Mrs Russell, and Laura and Jake, Tesco Staff.Yours,James McCorkindale,McCorkindale School of Dancing.Sir,On Monday evening, July , five sacks of tin cans had been placed in the clear glass bin in Tesco#s car park. Some sort of gathering must have taken place over the weekend. You cannot run a countryyou can#t distinguish between a glass bottle and a tin can.At least something sensible is going to be done about the Rest and Be Thankful road. It was acceptable to try to prevent the hillside from being washed onto the roadway. It has been obvious for several months,not years, that that was not possible.At last someone has seen thata wide trench is dug between the hillside and the road, the hillside can still be washed down but will not reach the roadway.Yours,James W Mackay,Campbeltown.

title: campbeltown rallies to independence march
story: The independence march through Campbeltown on Saturday was a huge success and put a real zest for le back into the town which has been too long forgotten.That was the view of organiser Manny Singh who despite his apparent sacking from the All Under One Banner organisation was very much still in charge at the Campbeltown march.Afterwards he said: #It was a huge success for Campbeltown and the biggest demonstration for decades. There was a lot of spirit and a feeling that a number of towns in Scotland which have been forgotten, like Campbeltown, will not be left behind after independence.#He put the turnout at more than , and added: #The fact that the march extended theof Longrow gives a fair indication of the numbers who were there.He also told the Courier this week that he remained the #legal indentity# of the All Under One Banner group, despite a bitter public row among the hierarchy which looks like splitting the group in two.It was the biggest rally held in the town in recent years with marchers coming from as far afield as Aberdeen and Alloa and as well as Oban, Glasgow and Islay, with many travelling on the weekend ferry from Ardrossan.#It really exceeded expectations and made a big splash in the town, Ron Wilson of Yes Kintyre told The National.#There was a real buzz as people came early and most of the hotels were booked up. The pubs and cafes were busy so it was good for local businesses. Campbeltown is a Yes town and it was brilliant to have all these people come here. Local people were coming off the pavements and joining the procession so it created a good, positive vibe.Pro-Unionists opponents held their own counter demonstation. However, the march went off without any incident and there were no arrests, with only one warning which was drug related.A spit of rain earlier in the day failed to develop into poor weather as the marchers would round the town to hear speakers and listen to musicians at the rally at Kinloch Green.Mr Wilson said he was particuarly pleased at the turnout as there had been some confusion over whether the march would go ahead due to internal sions within the hierachcy of All Under One Banner, which has organised independence marches across the country.Following Mr Singh#s sacking, founder Neil Mackay resigned from his position on its national executive pending an internal investigation.Pro-UK Unionist group A Force For Good met the march on the shore front and say they filmed and counted the marchers, as they have at previous events, and afterwards claimed the turnout was just .Director, Alistair McConnachie, said: #All Under One Banner is basically the marching wing of the SNP. AUOB, and SNP MPs and MSPs, lie about the numbers which attend their marches, sometimes up to  or  times.#Unfortunately, they are not challenged by the Scottish media. The good news is that A Force For Good has a presence at every AUOB march. We bear witness to the huge value of the United Kingdom.  Our #Thin Red Line# stands for everyone who likes being British, who likes the UK, and who wants us to stay together.#A group from Barrowfield at the Campbeltown cross ahead of the march. story: A young cricket star with Campbeltown connections has been starring for Scotland under-s in the team’s quest to qualy for the World Cup.Teenager Liam Naylor # who lives in Liverpool but whose mother Marie Naylor is originally from Campbeltown # and his compatriots have been in The Netherlands for a week-long qualying round that has seen them take on the host country, as well as Ireland, France, Jersey and Denmark.And while Liam, , began playing the game in Merseyside with Alder Cricket Club at the age of , rising through the ranks to turn out for the club’s first team as a seam bowler at , he has since earned a two-year scholarship to play cricket and study sport at the Wellington School, in Taunton, Somerset, after being scouted by Steffan Jones, a household name in English county cricket as a fast bowler, and as a coach in Indian cricket for Rajasthan Royals.As an avid Liverpool FC fan, Liam regularly attends matches at Anfield with his mum, sister Hannah and football-mad dad Phil Naylor, but Marie explained how Liam’s love for batting sports also runs in the family.Marie said: ‘I spent many happy summers playing rounders with my friends on Meadows Field growing up, and coming back to Campbeltown Liam would always want to play cricket # not rounders, but cricket # on that same field.‘Liam has already represented Scotland under-s, so to go away with the under-s is another really exciting opportunity. title: thought for the week week 31
story: Imagine. Imagine a world where no one was hungry, a world where no one was homeless, a world where the most powerless were given a voice.Imagine. Imagine a world like that.John Lennon penned these words of hope and inspiration when he wrote his famous song, #Imagine#.It is worth looking again at his words:#Imagine there#s no countriesImagine all the peopleYou, you may say I#m a dreamerImagine no possessionsImagine…#Could we, in reality, imagine such a world As the problems of our country and our world grow deeper, we need some dreamers.We need a voice of hope, not of hate.We need a voice of truth, not of turbulence.We need a voice that will inspire with values of integrity and honour.We need a voice to show us the way in these disturbing times.We need a voice we can trust.There are many voices shouting at us these days, there are many voices that do not call for peace at this time.In all the shouting and the arguing and the anger, let us take time to find a quiet place and listen.Let us listen for that whisper, the voice of truth, the one that comes from the Prince of Peace himself.Imagine.

title: work-long-awaited-port-seton-sports-hall-set-start-soon
story: The much-anticipated hall has been in the pipeline for several years and plans for the expansion were lodged with East Lothian Council more than two years ago.The local authority says that contracts for the work are expected to be awarded this month, with contractors expected to start on site in September.The new hall will allow the centre to offer more activities and a wider range of sports than ever before, including basketball, badminton, tennis and football.It will also allow centre regulars such as East Lothian Gymnastics Association the chance to train with a proper run-up to their apparatus.The new hall, which will be an extension to the main building, will measure  metres by  metres and also includes storage areas.There will be a new lobby created to link the hall to the cafe area of the main centre building and it will provide capacity for more classes to be held in the centre.It is being built to the west of the current building, with plans to move the childrenrsquos play area, re-siting it beside the new hall, in an area which will be better positioned for parents to keep an eye on youngsters.A report to the council revealed there had been a delay on the work as the ldquotechnical specs were revised to bring it within budget.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe main elements of our investment at Port Seton Community Centre to provide a new sports hall with provision for gymnastics remains unchanged.ldquoIn order to secure best value and deliver the project within budget, we have revisited the technical specications for the project.ldquoWe now anticipate awarding the contract for works in late July with contractors starting on site in September.ldquoWe are working with the centrersquos management group to keep them involved as the project progresses.

They are just normal people at the end of the day.ldquoWe talked about ious things ndash they wanted to know about good places to go eat in Edinburgh, ious local spots and seemed to like East Lothian and Edinburgh in general.Other golfers stepping into the hot seat included Lee Slattery, who finished tied for ninth at the competition, and West Lothianrsquos Stephen Gallacher.Former Ross High School pupil Connor, who is the owner and barber at Chaps Barber in Newcraighall, revealed that although the haircuts were complimentary, the golfers did offer generous tips and said: ldquoThey were pretty good ndash I cannot complain.Connor, who has been a barber for the last  months, got the chance through a family connection.His older sister Christy, , is dating North Berwick golfer Grant Forrest, who finished tied for rd at the event.Connor, , who plays golf at Longniddry Golf Club, was able to cheer Grant on.He said: ldquoThe European Tour got involved with Grantrsquos management company Bounce Sports.ldquoFrom there, they got the ball in motion and all the logistics of it.ldquoThese things take massive planning to get things done and it was quite a y process.ldquoIt took about two or three months to get it all finalised.

title: plea-save-former-dolphin-hotel-s-late
story: New le could be breathed into the former Dolphin Hotel, which included a bar and lounge on the ground floor.The bar closed in February  but the upstairs, which was used as a hotel, has not been in use for nearly  years.Developer The Dolphin InnLtd wants to ensure the building, on Dunbarrsquos Queenrsquos Road, has a future.Plans have been lodged with East Lothian Council for a hostel, complete with reception and cafe, on the ground floor.Under the proposals, the first floor would have four bedrooms, with three shower rooms and a family suite. The second floor would feature six bedrooms, with four bath or shower rooms, and the top floor acting as a managerrsquos flat.The developer has highlighted the poor state of the building and said that the first and second floors were ldquoseriously affected by dry rot and are unsafe.A ldquopriority of repairing the building and eradicating the advancing dry rot has been identied, with the developer keen to bring the building back into use ldquobefore itrsquos too late.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, told the Courier she had previously seen inside the building and it was ldquoin a terrible state of repair.She said: ldquoAnybody that wants to come in and invest high-quality renovation in Dunbar is to be welcomed.ldquoIt is wonderful that the building, which is so prominent, is in line for a facelt.ldquoMy understanding is that the client group is going to be aimed at walkers and surfers and, again, that would be warmly welcomed.Attempts had previously been made to see the building re-open as a hotel. However, there was ldquono interest from potential developers.A design and access statement, which is included within the planning application, notes: ldquoItrsquos quite possible there has been no demand for this property to be retained as a hotel due to competition in the immediate vicinity, namely The Royal Mackintosh Hotel on Station Road and the Hillside Hotel on Queenrsquos Road.Two years ago, Dunbar Trout Farm Ltd, was given permission to transform the building. Those plans, approved in August , included the creation of two shops and four flats.However, the design and access statement reads: ldquoSince this permission was obtained, despite evidence of marketing, there has been insufficient interest for its use as shops and flats.ldquoOur clientsrsquo proposal is to redevelop the building for use as a hostel, providing accommodation to visitors to Dunbar, [primarily] those who would take part in the large number of outdoor activities available within the area.ldquoA small flat-roofed single-storey extension to the side is proposed to provide associated laundry room.

title: tranent-39-s-scott-glynn-retires-after-dinner-circuit
story: Tranent charity founder Scott, who was recently awarded an MBE, tweeted that his health journey has taken ldquoa massive tumble and would therefore quit his after-dinner speaking gigs. He had a liver transplant in .Tributes and testimonies to his talent have been pouring in across social media, with many quoting lines from his routine, as well as lsquoget well soonrsquo and lsquokeep fightingrsquo messages.A Crowdfunding page has been set up to support Scott - the founder of the hugely successfulWalk with Scott charity treks -and has raised more than pound, so far.Anyone wishigto donate should visit justgiving crowdfunding davie-martin-

title: charlotte-cowan-takes-west-highland-way-memory-dad-kenny
story: Charlotte Cowan, from North Berwick is completing the walk, over five days, beginning on September .The -year-old is raising money for the townrsquos Edington Cottage Hospital, the place where her dad spent his last week.Charlottersquos dad Kenny Cowan was a support worker but a joiner by trade.Having lost her mother when she was a baby, Kenny raised Charlotte and her brother as a single parent with help from her gran and other family members.Charlotte, who lives on Lochbridge Road, had a great relationship with her dad.ldquoI was very close to him and practically attached to his hip when I was little, I would go everywhere with him, she told the Courier.ldquoHe was such a genuinely lovely guy, no one had a bad word to say about him.ldquoHe was a big personality in the community and was so well known and loved by many.Kenny played bowls for Dirleton Bowling Club, darts in North Berwick and was an honorary member at the townrsquos rugby club for  years.He had been suffering with a bad back on and off for years, thinking it was sciatica.But in October last year the pain was getting worse, to the point he struggled to get out of bed.Two months later, Kenny was told he had stage four aggressive cancer in his spine which had spread and nothing more could be done.It was his last wish to be able to go to Edington Cottage Hospital before he died.ldquoUp until his very last day he had lots of visitors in to see him, Charlotte said.ldquoI donrsquot think [the Edington] had ever known as many visitors.ldquoHe was laughing and joking and listening to his beloved Runrig.Kenny died on January , aged .Charlotte said: ldquoIt was extremely hard to lose him. It was one of the hardest things to go through but we take comfort in the fact he said he would always be watching over us and we had time at the end to get to say goodbye to him and he knew how loved he was.She has always wanted to walk the West Highland Way, being a lover of the outdoors and a keen hiker.ldquoFamily and work commitments always seemed to get in the way or I just thought it would be too expensive, she said.ldquoWhen my dad passed away, I wanted to do something for him it kind of gave me the push to stop putting it off and actually go for it.ldquoI just want to do something big in his honour.ldquoI would just like to raise a bit of money for the hospital as it is a huge part of our community.ldquoI went there with my children when they were young, my gran and nana spent time in there, and my dadrsquos dad spent his last days in there also.ldquoMy dad was so well looked after that I just wanted to give something back, say thank you for looking after my dad and the community so well.In terms of the walk she is excited about the challenge ahead, saying: ldquoI canrsquot wait for the walk, I know itrsquos going to be hard doing it over five days, which is an average of  miles a day. I just hope my feet are up to the challenge!Charlottersquos training is going well, having already completed practice walks on her route to check out the terrain.She has also walked up Ben Nevis and completed the Three Lochs Way in one day.ldquoI havenrsquot managed any consecutive days walks yet as with kids and work itrsquos not easy to fit in, she said. ldquoBut when schools go back in August, I will have a month to get last bits of training in. I do feel ready, though, definitely.ldquoA bad blister could ruin it all or an injury, but hopefully neither will happen. Irsquove just got to be as prepared as possible and keep my fingers crossed for the rest.Charlotte is not doing the challenge solo, with three walking friends going along with her.She said: ldquoSupport has been great, everyone is getting behind me and wishing me well and helping with sponsors. I really appreciate any money raised.She said a special thank you to her step-mum Heather, who met Kenny when Charlotte was  and later married him, saying: ldquoShe has been a huge support for me through everything and I really want to thank her for that.On her goals, she said: ldquoJust being able to give something back is all Irsquod like to achieve.ldquoWe will be celebrating with a big gin at the end! The feeling of achievement and knowing I will have done my dad proud will be the best feeling, though. He would probably have called me crazy for doing this as he did for a few things I had done, but I know hersquod be proud and thatrsquos all I want to do.Donate at uk.virginmoneygiving CharlotteCowan or via the sponsor sheet at Charlottersquos work, Smithrsquos Pharmacy, North Berwick High Street.

title: dog-walker-stalker-sentenced-next-year
story: David Page followed and filmed the woman for over five years after he spotted her Labradoodle allegedly becoming overly-friendly with his greyhound-cross while out on a walk with his pet.Page, , used a GoPro camera, a mobile phone and a long-lens camera to intimidate the woman and her family when they took their dog out for walks in the town.The woman was forced to call the police and, after denying the allegations, Page, of Castle Street, eventually stood trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last year.He was found guilty of causing fear and alarm to the woman and her family between January  and October  following the trial last July.He was also found guilty of a separate charge of using abusive language towards employees at East Lothian Council during a phone call on October , .Sherf Alistair Noble issued Page with a four-year non-harassment order banning him from approaching the woman and deferred full sentence to last week.However, when Page appeared in court, the sherf again deferred sentence on him to January next year.

title: great-music-tap-belhaven-brewery-hosts-300th-birthday-festival
story: The Belhaven th Birthday Bash features household names including Dougie Mac-Lean and Capercaillie, as well as up-and-coming bands such as Assynt and Kinnaris Quintet.The special event, which takes place in Dunbar on September , is being billed as a celebration of the best of Scottish music and beer.Gordon Muir, marketing controller and festival organiser, said: ldquoItrsquos not every year you get to mark a milestone as big as  years and so we wanted to celebrate this with Belhavenrsquos two loves, beer and Scottish music.ldquoBelhavenrsquos th Birthday Bash is the ultimate party for those fans and our loyal customers who enjoy nothing more than a few beers and great live music.ldquoWersquove plenty of things for the whole family to do, including storytelling and games for youngsters, selfie sessions and music masterclasses for the teens, and beer tastings and brewery tours for the adults.The main stage showcases the best in Scottish traditional music and top talent from Scotlandrsquos folk scene over the last three decades.Multi-award-winning Scottish contemporary folk band Breabach are joined by Highland outfit Tide Lines Niteworks, who have become renowned for their fusion of electronica and folk music and Elephant Sessions and Talisk ndash both winners of Belhavenrsquos annual bursary for innovation in Scottish music.Belhaven Breweryrsquos beers will be served from tap bars around the brewery grounds, including , a specially brewed birthday celebration pale ale. There will be food stalls and merchandise stalls.Meanwhile, the brewery gardens host family activities and music masterclasses.Gates open at am, with the first act taking to the stage at noon.The following day, the brewery is hosting an open day between am and pm.More information at belhaven birthday-bash

title: flexible-fundraiser-flips-along-belhaven-bay-help-charity
story: Hugh Panton literally went head over heels to help Friends of the Earth Scotland as he backflipped for a mile along Belhaven Bay.The -year-old, who lives just a mile from the beach, on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road, told the Courier: ldquoI was graduating from the University of Aberdeen and wanted to do something a bit special.ldquoI have always wanted to do a fundraiser event but never really had the time when I was at university.ldquoI decided I would do something that capitalises on my skills as a flipping enthusiast and had a couple of ideas.ldquoI thought maybe I would try to do , flips in five days or something and then it just came to me to try to do a mile of flips.ldquoAt the time, it sounded quite ridiculous but I really wanted to try it.The former Dunbar Grammar School pupil spent three days last month working his way from west to east along the picturesque beach for the challenge, which took him about  hours to complete.Hugh, who has started work as an assistant countryside ranger at the Loch of the Lowes Nature Reserve, near Dunkeld, was not the only one on the beach, as he attracted curious glances from onlookers.Hugh, who studied geography at university, managed to raise more than pound, and said: ldquoI would go down to the bay and I go to the very far end where there are not too many people.ldquoAfter a wee while training before doing the event, people would be walking by and their heads just slowly started following me down the beach.ldquoThere were horse riders as well and the horses did not like it at all and I would have to wait for them to pass.The flips were broken down into blocks of five or  so Hugh could keep his bearings, with the talented tumbler completing about  flips over each of the three days ndash  in total.Kerrigan Bell, development manager for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: ldquoWersquore delighted that Hugh decided to raise much-needed funds.

title: airshow-lifeboat-fete-gullane-games-musselburgh-festival-spott-fete
story: The Courier has put together a list of five of the top things to do over Saturday and Sunday.Whether it is planes, boats, horses or much more, there is plenty to keep everyone occupied - eventhe weather isnt perfect.. Scotlands National AirshowBIG crowds are expected to flock to the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune on Saturday as Scotlandrsquos National Airshow takes place.And as well as all the aircraft initially announced, there are some exciting new additions to the line-up for the airshow, which takes place between am and pm, with the aerial displays set to commence from .pm.Despite todays poor weather, organisers said this morningthat the Met Office forecast "showednothing to prevent the Airshow going ahead today as planned".A Wildcat HMA  maritime attack helicopter,  Catalina flying boat and a  North American T Texan training aircraft are among the newbies.Joining them in their debut at the airshow are a Second World War Soviet Yakovlev Yak- fighter, a Westland Scout helicopter and a de Havilland Beaver utility aircraft.Also in the mix at the airshow are a Goodyear Corsair FG-D US wartime fighter bomber, Canadian T- Silver Star jet and an American P Thunderbolt Second World War fighter, while five members of the Wings Parachute Display Team drop in.As well as all the new additions, the aerial entertainment programme includes the RAFrsquos Supermarine Spitfire, Hawker Hurricane and Avro Lancaster from the RAF Battle of Britain Memorial Flight, as well as the modern-day Typhoon fighter jet.Aerobatic display team The Blades will take to the skies along with the AeroSuperBatics Wingwalkers, both performing some breathtaking tricks plus, much, much more.Tickets can be bought online, by calling    or on the gate on the day. Visit nms.ac.uk airshow for more details.. North Berwick Leboat FeteTHERErsquoS plenty of fun on offer this Saturday as North Berwick Leboat Fete takes place.The event, which runs between .pm and pm, starts with a parade along High Street before the crowning of this yearrsquos Leboat Queen, Theodora Nikolova, by Lady Dalrymple.The fete at Elcho Green and West Beach then opens at pm, with ious stalls and games on offer and a raffle.. Spott FeteAFTERNOON tea, games for children, stalls and music are all promised at Spott Village Fete.Teas are served in the village hall, with the event held on The Glebe from pm to pm.. Gullane GamesA WEEK of celebrations s to Gullane as the annual Gullane Games kicks off on Saturday and runs until next Saturday .The opening day is packed with sport ndash featuring golf, football and hockey.The under-srsquo golf competition starts at am on the childrenrsquos course.Football for under-s begins at pm at Memorial Park and P- hockey gets under way at .pm on the astroturf.Sunday sees a village treasure hunt from pm at the Mallard Hotel. Entry is pound per team, with maximum of five members per team children in primary school must be accompanied by an adult.. Musselburgh FestivalMUSSELBURGH festival is well under way, and there is still much to look forward to with fairground rides, fancy dress, a raft race and parades still on the horizon.Horses will be seen parading through the town tomorrowmorning as the traditional Rideout takes place,starting at am at Pinkie Pillars.While Pinkie St Peterrsquos Playing Field hosts Saturdayrsquos Festival Fun Day, with fairground rides, stalls, face painting, music and childrenrsquos entertainment filling the day with enjoyment for everyone.Festival Day will be capped with the even grander Festival Ball. Tickets are for sale at pound and can be purchased by contacting musselburghfestivalball@gmailSunday sees the fun continue as the Fisherrow Family Fun Day takes place at the harbour , featuring beach volleyball, beach rugby and beach tennis hand in hand with sandcastle competitions, crafts, a tug of war and a raft race.The Honest Lass and Honest Lad this year are Claire Dougal and Aidan Maguire, who have been busy throughout the week with their attendant Abbie Thomson.There have also been appearances from last yearrsquos Honest Lad and Honest Lass, Conor Scott and Katie McLaren.For more information about this yearrsquos festival, visit musselburghfestival.org

title: dunbar-39-s-bear-statue-expected-place-later-year
story: Discussions surrounding an eye-catching piece of artwork near the A have been ongoing for several years.Original proposals suggested Apollo, the Greek and Roman god of the sun, could find a home on the Spott Road roundabout on the busy road.However, it was eventually decided a bear would be located nearby.Renowned Scottish artist Andy Scott ndash responsible for the Kelpies, near Falkirk ndash is the man behind the -foot bear, which will stand on its hind legs.Dunbar Community Council said it had received confirmation from applicants Hallhill Development Ltd that work should start towards the end of September and last for five weeks.East Lothian Council initially refused planning permission for the sculpture, which will be near the townrsquos Asda and McDonaldrsquos, but approval was finally given by the Scottish Government, with conditions from Transport Scotland.Ken Ross, from the applicants, previously told the Courier: ldquoThis piece of art will not only contribute to the emerging identity of Dunbarrsquos new gateway but has the potential to draw people into the area to find out more about John Muir.

title: revamped-aubigny-swimming-pool-revealed
story: Work got under way at the pool and health suite within the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre in April and ndash after a delay ndash the pool re-opened on Monday.Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, which manages the sports centre, was confident visitors would be impressed with the changes.He said: ldquoIn my view, the only way to improve it would be to knock it down and start from scratch, which was not an option for us.ldquoIn terms of the amount of work and the quality of the work carried out, I think you will be absolutely delighted.Essential maintenance and interior deacutecor works have been carried out at the sports centre over several weeks.During the work, the two pools were drained, with a new light, bright ceiling covering the outdated wood cladding.New lighting, roofing works and ceiling and wall cladding work has been carried out surrounding the pool, with new lockers and other alterations in the changing rooms.Tiles were also given a thorough clean ahead of the re-opening.The new-look pool was revealed to enjoyleisure members and politicians last Friday.Among those attending the opening was East Lothian MP Martin Whitfield, along with Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillors Shamin Akhtar and Craig Hoy.Ms Akhtar was impressed with what she saw and said: ldquoI am delighted with the work.ldquoThe swimming pool looks absolutely fantastic.ldquoI think it will be really well received by the local community and I think it is going to be really well used.Ward colleague Mr Hoy agreed, saying: ldquoItrsquos fantastic to see the Aubigny pool re-opening and to see an entirely new look awaiting local residents.ldquoPools and sports centres arenrsquot just leisure facilities, they are le savers ndash helping our communities fight chronic diseases such as diabetes and heart disease.ldquoItrsquos vital we continue to invest in our gyms and swimming pools in East Lothian.The facility is one of East Lothianrsquos original sports centres and originally opened its doors as Haddington Swimming Pool in September . The site consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Before the temporary closure, the facility welcomed about , bathers each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, swimming club training, school and public use.

title: attempts-bring-bugs-back-john-muir-way
story: Charity Bugle Scotland aims to boost insect and bug numbers along or near the Dunbar-to-Helensburgh John Muir Way by encouraging wildflower-rich habitats at selected sites.A spokesperson for the charity said: ldquoThe UK has lost over  per cent of species-rich grassland since the s with dramatic declines in associated wildle including native bees, butterflies, hoverflies and beetles.Phase two of the pollinator project has recently been completed.There were  habitat sites in total that were seeded and rewilded, including four sites in East Lothian: Prestongrange Museum, by Prestonpans Cockenzie Primary School Longniddry Wood and at Waterston House, Aberlady.A new wildflower meadow was created on-site at Prestongrange Museum with help from the staff and volunteers Cockenzie Primary teachers and pupils lent a helping hand to create a bee garden in the school grounds and wildflower seeds were distributed to Waterston House to enhance their existing wildle garden and orchard. At Longniddry Wood, the charity worked with East Lothian Council to plant new bulbs and seeds.All of the habitats along or close to the John Muir Way were supported by funding from the Scottish Government and the Greggs Foundation, as well as the Central Scotland Green Network and the local authorities.Joanna Lindsay, conservation officer for Bugle Scotland said: ldquoCommunities all along the John Muir Way have contributed to enhancing their local greenspaces for wildle through this project and have learned about the importance of protecting our pollinator populations. Hopefully this time next year, walkers and cyclists using the route will enjoy seeing these sites buzzing with le.Roseanna Cunningham MSP, Environment Secretary, added: ldquoIrsquom pleased to support initiatives like this which help to create ideal habitats for our flora and fauna.

title: east-lothian-town-features-charlie-laidlaw-39-s-new-book
story: The Space Between Time uses Edinburgh, as well as North Berwick, in its story.Gullane author Charlie Laidlaw was pleased to say his second book ndash following on the heels of The Things We Learn When Wersquore Dead ndash had already attracted praise from reviewers.He said: ldquo[Before its official release] it had something like  reviews on Goodreads and all have been four or five stars.ldquoThat is encouraging because when you write a book you have confidence in it but you have no idea what kind of reaction other people will have to it.ldquoWhat  is encouraging is that the rights to an audio book and large print version have been snapped up.Actress Kate Okello, who starred in Stan  Ollie, will narrate the newly-released book.The Space Between Time, which has been published by Accent Press, tells the story of a young girl growing up in a dysal family and ultimately coming to terms with herself.Emma is the daughter of a beautul and loving mother, and her father is one of the most famous film actors of his generation.She is also the granddaughter of an eccentric and obscure Italian astrophysicist.But as her seemingly charmed le begins to unravel, and Emma experiences love and tragedy, she ultimately finds solace in her once-derided grandfatherrsquos theorem on the universe.The story offers the metaphor that everyone is connected, even to those that have been loved and not quite lost.Charlie, , says his books are ldquocharacter driven, with plans for a third book ndash Love Potions and Other Calamities ndash due to be released later this year.The Space Between Time has been three years in the making, with Charlie having to fit writing in around running his own media consultancy business in the county.He said: ldquoI carry around a notebook with me andan idea comes to me I will put it down.

title: tranent-woman-honoured-pope-services-catholic-church
story: Fiona Stewart, now resident of Banff in Aberdeenshire, was awarded the Benemerenti Medal for her  years of service to the church.Fiona has been singing at Tranentrsquos St Martinrsquos RC Church since she was eight, later playing guitar at services, and continued to do so throughout her teenage years and even came back on weekends when she studied at the University of Dundee.After moving to Banff in the early s, Fiona, , dedicated herself to her job as a senior solicitor at Aberdeen Council and to Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Banff ndash as secretary of the parish council, chair of the finance committee and  years as chief musician.This commitment to her church and its parish was recognised by the congregation, who nominated her.The nomination then went to the Bishop, who agreed, and took the request to Rome, where he collected the Papal award for Fiona, surprising her with it last month.She said: ldquoI had no idea this was happening. I was getting ready to play the guitar for the end of service when Father Colin Stewart presented me with the award.ldquoI was in shock, there was a large applause, and I was just shaking my head thinking lsquono wayrsquo!ldquoI was presented with a medal and a framed certicate from the Pope, and the congregation had made me a cake shaped like a guitar, which was really lovely. We had a tea party to celebrate.ldquoIrsquom still really taken aback. People kept saying to me lsquoit usually gets presented to really old people and rarely to womenrsquo so you can imagine how proud I am to have received it.ldquoMy parents are also really proud and astonished!ldquoI canrsquot wait for my visit to see them and come back to St Martinrsquos to play and sing, as I always do when Irsquom through. Itrsquos part of who I am, and I love coming back.Fionarsquos parents, William and Zuzanna Stewart, live on Tranent High Street.

title: east-lothian-foodbank-manager-peter-dicker-meets-queen
story: Peter Dicker, manager of the Tranent-based foodbank, and his we Linda Hamilton, area fundraiser for the NSPCC, were invited to the Royal Garden Party at the Palace of Holyroodhouse at the start of the month and found themselves unexpectedly in line to meet Her Majesty.Peter, of Port Seton, said: ldquoWe turned up at the party, and it was spectacular! I bumped into a friend of mine from The Royal Company of Archers ndash they serve as the Queenrsquos bodyguards when shersquos in Scotland ndash and we were chatting away when he said: lsquoDo you fancy meeting her, then rsquoldquoWe were gobsmacked as he took us to a line of people who were waiting to meet her and put us in it. We couldnrsquot believe it.ldquoShe was really lovely too. When she stopped, she asked me what I did, and I told her and she said: lsquoYou must be really busy at the moment.rsquo I answered: lsquoYes, with the introduction of Universal Credit, we have been very busy.rsquoldquoThen she asked: lsquoWhere does the food come from rsquo So I explained how the donation system worked and how we had just done a collection from the Tescos across East Lothian of , kilos of food and explained how we organised it and bagged it up and all the volunteers. She seemed really interested.ldquoShe spoke to Linda about her work with the NSPCC as she used to be its patron. Then she moved on.ldquoLinda and I just looked at each other and said: lsquoWow! We just met the Queen!rsquoPeter, who has been manager of the foodbank, on Civic Square, since , admitted: ldquoIt took days for my we and I to get our heads around it. We were so excited.ldquoI said to Linda on the way home: lsquoShe had such wise eyes.rsquo I mean, imagine all she has seen and everyone she has met. It really was wonderful.The Queen hosts four garden parties a year ndash three at Buckingham Palace and one at Holyrood ndash with more than , people attending in total.

title: top-fringe-talent-appear-brunton
story: Top Fringe talent to appear at The BruntonDougie MacLean: Photo: Rob McDougall. MANDATORY CREDIT: PIC - ROB MCDOUGALL wwltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtw.RobMcDougallltspan classtruncate-full-screengtAs Venue , the theatre will host  performances suitable for all ages.This year, The Brunton is producing the musical theatre production Oliver! in association with Tommie Travers, combining Charles Dickensrsquo classic story and characters with Lionel Bartrsquos score. This new venture will be a core part of The Bruntonrsquos  Fringe programme. Up to  young people will participate in a musical theatre summer school experience with the opportunity to perform on The Brunton stage and be part of the  Fringe.The Classical at One series gives friends the chance to have a light lunch in the upstairs bar from noon before enjoying an hour of classical music in Venue  a pm. title: north-berwick-pipe-band-enjoy-taking-part-folklore-festival-germany
story: The festival was held in the Spree-Neisse district in the east of the country between June  and June .The band performed a iety of Highland dance and traditional Scottish music to audiences across three towns.They were joined by dancers from the Dunedin Dance Academy.Other acts at the festival included fellow musicians and dancers from countries such as Belarus, Poland, Belgium, India and Nepal.In light of their recent performance, the band are now preparing for upcoming events.First is their public show, which takes place every Wednesday evening in the Lodge Grounds during July and August. These performances are free to attend and begin at .pm.On Saturday they are leading the parade for North Berwick Leboat Fete, then on August  they are taking part in the North Berwick Highland Games and parade.The band are holding open practices on Monday evenings at .pm during July and August. These take place in St Andrew Blackadder Church Hall and are open to everyone of all ages.Visit northberwickpipeband or phone pipe major Eddie McFadzean on   for more information.

title: lighting-project-complete-historic-st-mary-39-s-parish-church
story: Substantial work was carried out at St Maryrsquos Parish Church over the first six months of the year to install a modern lighting system.A total of pound, has been spent on the scheme, which was completed last month.Stewart Meikle, an elder at the historic Haddington church, said the new lighting system was already making a massive dference.He said: ldquoThat is the project complete.ldquoThe benefits are ious: the interior of the building has been transformed, with the lighting highlighting all the features, the archways, the ceiling etc. We are also saving a lot of energy and making it easier to maintain.The improvements have been in the planning for several years. Mr Meikle paid tribute to AB Lighting and Nicholson Bros for their input in making the project a reality.Funding has come from a iety of sources.Mr Meikle told the Courier: ldquoIt has come from a mix of the churchrsquos own money from the sale of the manse, some of that has been allocated.ldquoThere was a lot of local fundraising held, including an art exhibition, and we have had personal donations from a fair few people.ldquoWe had grant applications from Viridor, WREN are providing money, and Tyne Esk LEADER are pitching in. There were ious small grants from Persimmon and Tesco Bags of Help.Work started in January, with the scheme split into two phases, which limited entry and exit from the church.Mr Meikle said the plan had been to get the work carried out in the first half of the year to ensure the building was looking at its best for the Lammermuir Festival, which takes place in September, and Armistice Day in November.He added: ldquoIt is pretty impressive.ldquoWe have had only a positive reaction from people in the church.ldquoLammermuir Festival are delighted with the lighting and we have not had anyone say a bad word about it.The Very Rev Dr John Cairns, interim moderator at St Maryrsquos, also paid tribute to all those involved.He said: ldquoMany congratulations to all the team who have seen this through to completion, from the contractors to our own property and finance folk.ldquoAbove all, a particular debt is owed to Stewart Meikle, for without his commitment and drive it would not have been achieved so effectively and timeously.ldquoThe lighting scheme was an ambition of [former minister, the late] Jenner Macrae and, like so much  she gave in her ministry, provides us with a heritage and a firm base from which to move into the next phase of St Maryrsquos le.

title: housebuilder-told-apologise-ormiston-residents
story: The housing firm was hauled before East Lothian Councils planning committee after it was discovered they had created a new access and put a sales caravan in place on the Limeylands site, in Ormiston, without seeking approval.And despite making a public apology for the move, councillors refused to give the changes planning permission instead rejecting a retrospective application and giving them two months to remove it.Councillors criticised Barratt for failing to engage with the local community and creating a feeling within local residents that there was a "lack of respect" for them.They were also told a sub contractor employed by the firm had mistakenly chopped down a mature tree which had not been in their plans causing further upset in the village.Councillor Willie Innes told the housebuilders that while he believed their actions were "misadventure" rather than "malicious" they could not be allowed to go unnoticed.And he warned the firm the situation in the village was "really a mess".Residents in Ormiston had opposed the plans to build  homes at the site off Limeylands Road, when they were first put forward five years ago.East Lothian Council rejected the original plans but the housing firm took their case to the Scottish Government Report who overturned the decision allowing them to go ahead with the housing.The planning committee were told that Barratt had now created a car park and sales caravan at the site with an access from the road, none of which were included in the approved plans.Mr Innes said: "What Barratt needs to understand is that they are creating a feeling in the commuity that Barratt does not respect them."The commuity opposed the original application and Barratt are holding it against them."I do not think that is the case, I think it is misadventure rather than malice. Barratt need to get round the table with the community."Jason Watt, from Barratt, told the committee that the company apologised for any concerns it has caused and was looking into improving its communication with the local community councily.He said the access created for the sales caravan was temporary and only in place while construction of the first home was carried out for health and safety reasons.However Mr Innes urged fellow committee members to reject a application approving the changes made saying Barratt needed to go back to the community and "rebuild its relationship" with them.The committee voted to reject the application by six votes to four.

title: craft-show-slot-joy-talented-jeweller-hannah-scott
story: Jeweller Hannah Scott will join  others in Edinburgh between next Fridayand August  to showcase her work.The second floor of White Stuff on the Capitalrsquos George Street will play home to a iety of craft and design pieces all made in Scotland, from cushions and textiles to jewellery, ceramics and glass.Hannah grew up near the beach in Cornwall but now lives in Musselburgh.She graduated from the Royal College of Art and Glasgow School of Art.She gathers inspiration for her work through maps, cityscapes and textures of the shoreline.Her most recent lsquoCoastline Collectionrsquo allows people to tell their own stories and capture their memories.Also on offer at the Craft Scotland Summer Show are maker-led workshops, which include hand weaving, willow weaving and paper folding.August  will see people being shown traditional bookbinding, while six days later, on August , attendees can learn how to create colour, pattern and textures on fabrics.Children aged  to  can get involved in young maker workshops, a new element for .Irene Kernan, Craft Scotland director, said: ldquoAt Craft Scotland we are incredibly privileged to be surrounded by beautul craft and engage with talented makers on a daily basis.ldquoKnowing the wealth of amazing work being made in Scotland, wersquore excited to be able to share so much of that at this yearrsquos show.ldquoWith the largest number of makers ever taking part this year,the Summer Show is the best place to see whatrsquos fresh and new in contemporary craft and the best place to discover new talents who are exploring interesting materials and themes.ldquoItrsquos particularly encouraging to see so many makers who will show their work with us for the first time.The Craft Scotland Summer Show is free to enter more information can be found at craftscotland.org

title: cash-boost-musselburgh-preston-lodge-rugby-clubs
story: Cash boost for two county rugby clubsRoyal Bank Rugby Force  SA :Cash boost for two county rugby clubsRoyal Bank Rugby Force  SA :The nationwide rugby programme launched by the bank in association with Scottish Rugby supports community clubs with funding each year to help them show off their passion for the game.Musselburgh RFC and Preston Lodge RFC will receive their prizes ahead of Royal Bank RugbyForce Weekend, which kicks off on Saturday, August , when clubs across the country will host a range of events as they launch the new season.Malcolm Buchanan, chair, Scotland Board, Royal Bank of Scotland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to award Musselburgh RFC and Preston Lodge RFC lsquoChampion Clubrsquo status in this yearrsquos Royal Bank RugbyForce programme.ldquo is set to be a thrilling year for Scottish rugby and we want to help make sure that our grassroots clubs across the country can benefit too.More than  clubs applied for Royal Bank RugbyForce support this year, and an official  of judges picked winners that demonstrated detailed and creative plans for their RugbyForce Weekend events that proudly show off their passion for the game.For , the campaign also focuses on helping clubs to make it easier for people to be part of a rugby community.Mr Buchanan said: ldquoThe standard of applications has been higher than ever and wersquore very proud to be able to provide funding and support for some truly fantastic community rugby projects across the country.ldquoRoyal Bank of Scotland has a long-standing commitment to rugby in Scotland. Over the  years which Royal Bank RugbyForce has been running, we have witnessed at first-hand the huge dference the programme has made to clubs, their members and the communities in which they play.ldquoWe would like to encourage everyone from club members to those thinking about getting involved in rugby to head to their local club for Royal Bank RugbyForce Weekend and become part of the rugby community.The nationwide programme supports clubs by providing funding to help them attract new members, make improvements to facilities and become more sustainable. With financial and practical support from the Royal Bank and professional advice from Scottish Rugby representatives, including Scotland and Glasgow Warriors legend Al Kellock, the programme has helped to deliver a range of benefits to clubs, including coaching clinics, boosting player numbers, attracting sponsorship and making pitch improvements.

title: income-boost-call-centre-dealing-non-east-lothian-calls
story: The council raised nearly pound, last year by providing services to outside agencies including its neighbours and is one of only two councils in Scotland which provides services for three local authorities at its centre for additional income.A report on the number of calls covered revealed that the contact centre dealt with , calls for Scottish Borders Council in its first year of providing call services for them.It also handled almost as many out of hours calls for Midlothian Council last year ndash , ndash than it did for East Lothian residents, who called the out of hours line , times.The centre reported receiving more than , service calls during the last financial year, with , for neighbouring authorities.An additional , calls were dealt with through its switchboard.In a report to the councilrsquos policy and performance review committee, it was revealed an additional five full-time workers were taken on by the community response team to deal with calls from the Scottish Borders.Eileen Morrison, head of customer services, said that funding from Scottish Borders covered the funding of additional staff and provided additional cash for the council.Councillors were told that taking on the contract had been a benefit to the centre, which has provided out of hours services for Midlothian Council for nearly a decade and also services for Castle Rock Edin and East Lothian Housing Association for additional income.Raymond McGill, contact centre manager, said: ldquoBy having a larger team everybody benefits. It is a strong and better service because we have been able to expand in this way.The report revealed services provided to Scottish Borders Council included community alarm and telecare calls and out of hours emergency services for social work and council repairs.And it revealed that the contact centre, which is based in Penston House, Macmerry, has also introduced an Election Line in recent years to deal with ldquomany election referendum calls in the run-up to an election.It was reported that  per cent of calls to the centre were answered or received call backs, slightly down from . per cent the previous year but still above the  per cent target. They had also experienced a dip in the number of calls answeredwithin  seconds, which fellto just under  per cent.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe total received from all parties for the services we provide on their behalf was almost pound, for  . This has enabled us to continue to invest in the services that we provide to our own residents through the contact centre.ldquoOur council is committed to working in new ways within the challenging financial climate.

title: funding-boost-charities-supporting-children-families
story: East Lothian Council has announced funding for eight third-sector organisations that work with children and young people.It has also set aside a further pound, to fund stays at a respite centre run by Aberlour Child Care Trust.A report by the councilrsquos head of children services revealed that money which had in the past been awarded to Aberlour directly in a single payment was now being set aside in a budget to pay for stays at Bankfoot Respite Centre, Prestonpans, on a case by case basis.The funding remains committed to the centre and will be overseen by the councilrsquos disability teamrsquos budget.Among the organisations receiving part of over pound, in grant funding is East Lothian Special Needs Playscheme, which received just over pound, to help it run respite day schemes during the school holidays in the coming year, while a further pound, has been awarded to Childrenst to support its kinship care and family support work.Action for Children, which also provides residential short breaks to give parents and carers of children and young people with severe and complex needs respite, received a grant of pound,.Home-Start East Lothian, which provides volunteer support to families with children under five in their homes, has been awarded just over pound,, and Cyrenians ConflictResolution Services, which works to keep young people in the family home, received pound,.An additional grant of pound, was given to ChildrenrsquosHospices Across Scotland .

title: morning-blues-county-rail-commuters-edinburgh-bound-line-blocked
story: North Berwick line services could not get to Waverley because the Edinburgh to London Sleeper had broken down near the capitals Abbeyhill area.Replacement bus services were put on by Scotrail but some rail users have complained that some buses were late or did not turn up at all.Scotrail announced on social media at about am that the Sleeper had been moved and that service wouldto normal from about am.

title: musselburgh-neighbours-scoop-30-000-thanks-postcode
story: The Stoneyhill Crescent neighbours netted the windfall when EH TD was announced as a winner with Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery on Tuesday.The prize was won as part of a special summer campaign where a lucky postcode will be announced as a winner of the poundK prize every day. All the players in that postcode then pick up a cheque worth poundK for every ticket that they play with.The duo were the only people playing with the winning postcode, and chose to remain anonymous, but had any of their neighbours been playing then they too would have picked up a cheque for pound,.Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery ambassador Matt Johnson sent his congratulations, saying: ldquoI couldnrsquot be more thrilled for the lucky Musselburgh pair picking up a prize today.ldquoI was lucky enough to spend the day in the town and got to enjoy an ice cream from the famous Lucarsquos, as well as visit Newhailes House, which is just minutes along the road from our winners and run by National Trust for Scotland - an organisation thatrsquos been awarded pound, in funding raised by players.ldquoWith Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery good causes win too and itrsquos great to see that, no matter where you go in the country, yoursquore never far from an organisation thatrsquos benefitted from the support of our players.With a minimum of  per cent from ticket sales going directly to charities, players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery have raised more than pound million to date for thousands of projects across Great Britain and internationally.This draw was promoted on behalf of Depaul which has received over pound. million thanks to player support.This funding is enabling the charity to tackle both the immediate and long-term effects of homelessness, helping it provide safe and stable futures for people who get left behind by society.For more information on Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery visit www.postcodelottery or Facebook and Twitter.

title: st-mary-39-s-parish-church-set-welcome-new-minister
story: The Rev Alison McDonald takes over the reins at St Maryrsquos Parish Church this eveningfollowing a unanimous vote of the churchrsquos congregation when she preached as sole nominee.Ms McDonaldrsquos induction takes place today before she is preached in by the Very Rev Dr Sheilagh Kesting on Sunday.She said: ldquoWhen I met the nominating committee, I was impressed by their vision to be an even greater positive force at the heart of the community. I am excited by all the creative possibilities of worship in the beautul church building.ldquoI am looking forward to progressing some of the ideas that the congregation have for the space, and to working in partnership across the town.ldquoWhen I preached as sole nominee, the people of St Maryrsquos couldnrsquot have been more genuine, warm, welcoming and friendly.ldquoI felt that they were looking forward to me beginning ministry with them as much as I am looking forward to becoming their minister.Originally from Dundee, Ms McDonald has been minister at Northesk Parish Church, Musselburgh, for more than  years.The -year-old said making the switch from Musselburgh was ldquoa wrench but she felt it was ldquotime to move.She said: ldquoIt has been a privilege to serve as minister of Northesk and in the communities of Fisherrow and Musselburgh. I am grateful for their love and support and thankful for the journey of faith that we have been on together over the years.St Maryrsquos has not had a permanent minister since the death last year of the Rev Jenner Macrae, who served the congregation for  years.Alison Meikle, session clerk, told the Courier: ldquoWe were delighted that Alison answered the call to be our minister. She has so much experience both as a parish minister and in the wider church.ldquoThings that struck a chord with us included her interest in working with families and across our growing community, her deep interest in music ndash which is so much part of worship at St Maryrsquos ndash and her commitment to ecumenical relations: St Maryrsquos works closely day-to-day with all our neighbouring churches.ldquoHer interests and ambitions fitted perfectly with ours.Ms McDonald was ordained in  in Budapest into a new post as Associate Minister at St Columbarsquos Church of Scotland and Mission Partner with the Reformed Church of Hungary.She ed to Scotland three years later, serving in Edinburgh before being called to Musselburgh in .Ms McDonald will be joined in Haddington by her husband, the Rev Sandy Horsburgh, who is minister of St Nicholas Buccleuch, Dalkeith, so that the manse of St Maryrsquos will also be the manse of St Nicholas Buccleuch.

title: adventurer-set-cross-australia-madagascar-run-across-iceland
story: But not this globetrotter. Despite clocking up more than , kilometres in ious challenges far too tasking for most ordinary humans, this itchy feet adventurer has set his sights on cycling and running across two of the worldrsquos biggest islands.For his latest solo challenge, Jamie is cycling from the south to the north of Australia before running theof Madagascar!The -year-old has only just finished running more than  kilometres across Iceland in less than a fortnight.He said: ldquoI am flying to Australia on August  and will be cycling , kilometres from Melbourne to Darwin up through the centre.ldquoThen, in November, I am flying to Madagascar to run , kilometres from north to south of the island.ldquoItrsquos a full-on year of adventuring!ldquoEvery time I look at a map I see a new adventure.ldquoI add them to the list and hopefully I find the time and funding to tick them off. The ultimate dream would be to swim the Atlantic. . . but thatrsquos a pipe dream at the moment!The trip to Iceland saw Jamie, from Whittingehame, run from the countryrsquos east to west coast in just  days after setting off on July .Clocking up about  kilometres a day, he had to contend with a range of obstacles ndash and only one hour of darkness a day.He said: ldquoThere were a number of big challenges including the remoteness of the F [the track that runs through the centre of Iceland], the weather which is cold, wet and windy, the weight of my backpack [about  kg] and the obvious challenge of running an ultra marathon distance day in and day out for  days.ldquoLuckily the  hours of daylight wasnrsquot too much of an issue. An eye mask normally helped and after running over  kilometres the body is ready to sleep.ldquoOn the plus side, I didnrsquot need a torch!Jamie slept on a blow-up mattress in a summer sleeping bag and bivi bag, under a tarpaulin.The former Belhaven Hill School, Stenton Primary School and Loretto School pupil caught the publicrsquos attention four years ago.He left his job at an international communications agency in London to run from Canadarsquos third largest city, Vancouver, to the capital of Argentina, Buenos Aires.The -month adventure raised more than pound, for CALM , Macmillan Cancer Support and WaterAid.Jamie iss busy putting pen to paper about the adventure, with more than , words already written.He told the Courier that writing the book was ldquoharder and more time consuming than the adventure itself.Since then, he has also scaled the highest mountain in the southern and western hemisphere ndash Aconcagua, in Argentina ndash and cycled from Sao Paulo, in Brazil, to Bolviarsquos La Paz. He has completed over , kilometres of adventuring over the last five years and visited  dferent countries.ldquoEven though my current adventures are as toughnot tougher than those in the past, people just assume I will successfully complete them, he said.ldquoI think I need to get better at making people realise what I am doing. But everyonersquos confidence in me helps me find the confidence in myself to perform.

title: stars-set-arrive-fringe-sea
story: Newsnightrsquos Kirsty Wark is among the first big names to appear as she discuss her new novel Fred MacAulay light ups the stage with his comedy and dance music pioneers Inner City will get the Simpson  Marwick Spiegeltent at the harbour shaking tomorrow evening.There is something for everyone during the August - extravaganza, from jazz performed in the North Berwick Fry and rock-pooling on the stunning North Berwick coast, to a chance to dance to pop sensation Be Charlotte and chat about all things Scottish with author Pete Irvine.The film segment of the festival welcomes local film Connect, along with Netflix hit Outlaw King, introduced by producer Danny McGrath, whereas those with an eye and ear for comedy can indulge in festival favourites Simon Evans, Janey Godley, Jamie MacDonald, Reginald D Hunter and last yearrsquos Edinburgh Comedy Award nominee Glenn Moore.Crime novel obsessives will have the opportunity to see Ian Rankin, as well as Alexander McCall Smith talking with Lord David Steel, Val McDermid with Sir Menzies Campbell, and appearances from John Niven, Malachy Tallack, Peter Irvine and Dr David Hetherington.There will also be talks presented by Speaker Buzz from inspirational women Mollie Hughes, Sara Sheridan, Jojo Fraser and Cal Major.All of this as well as singers Alexander OrsquoNeal and Eddi Reader, dance music act Groove Armada, rockers Idlewild, former Prime Minister Gordon Brown and famed wildle camera man Doug Allan makes this festival impossible to miss.Niall Middleton, festival co-ordinator, said: ldquoThe Spiegeltents are going up, the volunteers are gathering, and the performers are heading to North Berwick for  days of great entertainment. ldquoA great big thank you to all our sponsors and funding bodies for making this all possible.A host of local residents are also performing.For tickets, go to www.fringe bythesea

title: student-play-key-role-developing-cycling-scotland
story: Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil Louie Doig is one of nine who will represent the voice of young people in the sport.The , which is led by the sportrsquos governing body Scottish Cycling, aims to help influence and shape the future of Cycling in Scotland.It met for the first time at Scottish Cyclingrsquos headquarters at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow last month.Louie, who is about to start a degree in Sports Science at Glasgow University, has been part of Edinburgh Road Club since Summer , with his most recent success being a win in the Peebles CC Road Race earlier this year.He believes it is vital that Scottish Cycling has a  for young people to express their views.He said: ldquoI am really looking forward to the opportunity of working with my fellow members to develop a range of new projects to get more people cycling across Scotland.The  will be engaged in projects across the organisation ndash from regional development to events, and coaching and education.Craig Burn, Scottish Cycling CEO, said: ldquoI look forward to seeing the positive impact their dedication and passion for cycling in Scotland has.

title: new-life-breathed-back-haddington-39-s-victoria-inn
story: The Victoria Inn, on the townrsquos Court Street, has been shut for about a year but work to improve and re-open the building is now under way.Craig Douglas, who has now leased the premises, has vowed to restore the venue to its former glory.He said: ldquoIrsquom quite aware it has been empty for a while and it was being run by a management company for a short period of time.ldquoI want to bring stability to the area and we have to instil a bit of confidence in the locals. We are here for a long time not just a quick fix.He described it as ldquoa gorgeous building in a gorgeous area and said it ldquohuge potential.Work at the building, which is also home to The Avenue restaurant, will be carried out over three stages. A bar refurbishment is taking place at the moment and the new bar should be open in the coming weeksThen, attention will turn to the restaurant, with Mr Douglas keen to see that up and running by ldquomid to late August.Finally, work will be carried out on the five rooms above the premises.Mr Douglas, who has been involved in the industry in Edinburgh and Spain for a number of years, expected the rooms might not be in use until after the summer tourist season.He said: ldquoIt has got the facilities for us to do nice fresh, gastropub, homemade food. We are going to try to source local produce.The premises were previously owned by Greene King, who also own Belhaven Brewery.Mr Douglas, , from Edinburgh, who also runs The Old Aberlady Inn, said: ldquoI remember years ago I used to play rugby and I remember coming down to play Haddington.The Victoria Inn used to be absolutely packed.ldquoIf my memory serves me right, you would struggle to get a seat in the place.I would like to bring that back to the area again.Councillor Craig Hoy, who lives in the town, was happy to hear the prominent building was being brought back into use.He said: ldquoIf we can strengthen Haddingtonrsquos reputation as a food and drink destination at the heart of East Lothian, which is renowned for its farming and food production, it is something we can really build on in East Lothian and beyond. It is really important we give our support to the new restaurants and bars and I will certainly be doing that.

title: fringe-sea-gullane-games-innerwick-flower-show-among-attractions-weekend
story: The Courierhas put together a list of five of the top things to do between this evening and over the weekend.Whether it is football or flowers, horses or celebrities ormuch more, there is plenty to keep everyone occupied - eventhe weather isnt perfect.. Fringe by the SeaThe great and good of art, comedy and music are set to light up the countyrsquos coastline as North Berwickrsquos Fringe by the Sea festival launches today .Tonight, at pm, there is a chance to hear Newsnights Kirsty Wark discuss her new novel in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent.Later that evening, at pm, it is the turn of Fred MacAulay.The comedian and radio presenter will light up the stage with his comedy in the same venue.Meanwhile, in the towns community centre, NB Movies is showing Neither Wolf Nor Dog from pm.Tomorrow , former Masterchef winner, food writer and novelist Sue Lawrence visits the towns library.From pm, she will discuss her new novel Down to the Sea, which is set in Newhaven.Comedian Reginald D Hunter performs in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent from pm while there is live music from The Cuban Brothers from pm in the same venue.Sunday brings Edinburgh-based author, speaker, blogger and podcaster JoJo Fraser to the Lighthouse Spiegeltent from pm.Then, at pm in the same venue, DJ Monski Mouse will be playing some hits specially for the under-fives and parents carers.American RB singer-songwriter Alexander ONeal will be in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent from pm.There is plenty more on offer from todaythrough to August .For tickets, go to www.fringebythesea. Gullane GamesTHE curtain comes down on another memorable Gullane Games.This eveningfeatures a quiz night in the village hall for over-s.Tickets are pound for a team of four and available from gullanegames@outlookThe main event is Gullane Games Day itself tomorrow , plus parade.The parade under way at the childrenrsquos course at .pm.Fancy dress is optional and the theme of the parade is lsquoOur Natural Environmentrsquo.Prizes will be awarded for the best costume to age categories P and under, and P and above.The first race begins at .pm, while a tea tent, face painting, beat the goalie, assault course and tug of war are also on offer.Throughout the week, shops will be displaying lsquodeliberate mistakesrsquo in their windows for children to spot entry forms for the competition are available from the pharmacy on the opening day of the games.. Innerwick Flower ShowTHE th annual Innerwick Flower Show takes place on Saturday and promises a fun family day out.Flower displays, home baking, crafts and stalls of all kinds are on offer.Residents have been working hard to prepare their entries for a iety of competitions.Keen gardeners, crafters and bakers have been working around the clock to finesse their pieces.They will be entering competitions such as best sunflower, best bouquet, best Victoria sponge and largest cabbage, with the judges ready to make their decisions.Awards will be presented by Sheila Knox, whose late father Bob Denholm was a loyal supporter of the show and has an award named after him.Doors for the event open at pm for a .pm start.. Friday Night at the RacesMUSSELBURGH Racecourse is prepared for a busy summer spell with the first of four August meetings today .Friday Night at the Races is a firm favourite with the after-work crowd who want to let off steam after a hard week and ease into weekend downtime.Doors open at pm, which gives plenty of time ahead of the first race of the evening.With seven competitive flat races and prize money of more than pound,, the action gets underway at .pm with the Irish Stallion Farms EBF Median Auction Novice Stakes over seven furlongs.Feature race of the evening is the pound, Geoghegans sprint handicap over five furlongs at .pm.After the last race at .pm, racecourse favourites FunkWagen get the party started with summer tunes on the Loretto Lawn.For more information and to purchase tickets visit www.musselburgh-racecourse . FootballTHE new season got under way in East Lothian last Saturday and there are three home games to choose from on Saturday when you can go along and cheer on your local team.Musselburgh Athletic, Tranent and Preston Athletic are all at home, with kick-off at .pm at each game.Premier Division Musselburgh welcome Sauchie to East Lothian, with both teams still looking to get their first wins of the season.Musselburgh lost out to Dunbar, who scored a late winner ,last weekend.Meanwhile, Tranent, who have won one and drawn one of their opening two games, will play host to Jeanfield Swts.Finally, Preston Athletic welcome Stirling University and will be looking to build on their midweek - demolition of Tweedmouth Rangers.

title: ten-schools-new-headteachers---child-39-s-one
story: Building work is continuing at Letham Mains Primary School, Haddington, with Bruce Murray appointed the schoolrsquos first headteacher.Letham Mains Primary School pupils are currently being hosted within Haddington Primary School.Mr Murray, previously headteacher at Windygoul Primary School, is one of a number of new headteachers appointed.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, the local authorityrsquos spokeswoman for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoItrsquos great that our teachers and senior leaders choose to stay in our authority area and we can retain their experience and enthusiasm within our schools.ldquoIrsquom pleased to welcome new headteachers to our schools and look forward to further positive recruitment campaigns to fill the vacancies we have available.

title: rnli-crew-welcome-french-visitors
story: Keen swimmers Charlotte Bapao and Amelie Bobes have swapped the French village of Serres-Castet,  kilometres from Biarritz on Francersquos west coast, for a trip to Scotland.The exchange has come through Haddington and District Amateur Swimming Club, with the two youngsters visiting the RNLI to see the work that they do and to climb aboard the inshore leboat.Charlotte and Amelie, both , are members of the villagersquos swimming club, with exchange trips between the two swimming clubs dating back more than  years.More than  youngsters have enjoyed a -day stay with families throughout the county.Charlotte and Amelie have been staying with crew member Iain McDougall and family.A spokeswoman for Dunbar RNLI said: ldquoHis children, Jack, Katie and Robbie, joined the girls as fellow crew member Becs Miller told them all about the importance of staying safe in the water, while showing them the equipment we use and how our D-class inshore leboat helps us save lives at sea.

title: roadworks-close-one-main-routes-musselburgh
story: The B from Monktonhall Place to Musselburgh Services roundabout closes from midnight on Monday and is due to run until the end of August .The council said it has held extensive discussions with the contractor GTC, working on behalf of Persimmon Homes, to agree a -hour work programme that coordinates gas and power works to minimise disruption in the area.A council spokesperson said: "This closure is essential to put in place the utilities infrastructure required to support major new developments in the area."The contractor originally applied for a three week closure period."However our priority is to minimise disruption to residents and drivers so we have negotiated a -hour work programme that coordinates utility services to ensure this work is completed quickly and ahead of the schools ing."Diversion signs will be in place throughout the works. Passengers wanting to travel to Musselburgh from Old Craighall, Millerhill and Newton Village can use the shuttle service to the ERI and transfer to the  service ERI-Musselburgh.
