title: Rosemary Goring  Judge society by how happy we are  not how wealthy
story: The merest glimpse of the lives of moguls, oligarchs and millionaires tells you that. Are the faces staring out from the pages of glossy magazines shining with wellbeing  They might be tanned, toned, and expensively exfoliated, butany of these iniduals has a heart full of joy, it is unlikely to be as a result of their lestyle.In a recent talk, Nicola Sturgeon made an appeal to commonsense, stating what, deep down, most of us already know. She claims that when calibrating a countryrsquos standing and success, gross domestic product is not the most accurate measure. Not least among the misleading factors when using GDP as a guide is that its figures ignore unpaid carersrsquo work, yet put a value on illegal drug consumption. Just as worryingly, says Ms Sturgeon, ldquoIt values activity in the short term that boosts the economy eventhat activity is hugely damaging to the sustainability of our planet in the longer term.The First Ministerrsquos laudable aspiration is that ldquothe objective of economic policy should be collective wellbeing ndash how happy and healthy a population is, not just how wealthy a population is. Hoping to establish a fairer and truer scale of assessment, she is collaborating with the prime ministers of New Zealand and Iceland ndash women all, in charge of countries geographically on the fringes, who are prepared to challenge convention.Cynics might, of course, say that Ms Sturgeon is simply laying the groundwork for another independence bid, in which those predicting dire financial consequences will be brushed off as old-fashioned and out of touch by placing too much emphasis on our economic prowess. Yet with Brexit, not just economists but rabid Leavers acknowledge that orce from the EU will cause financial shockwaves. Clearly, this is a risk they think worth running. By the same token, idealists north of the Border, who want us to exit from the UK, often say that the possibility of diminished economic performance after independence would not in itself be a deal breaker. There are bigger issues at stake.That argument is for another day. At this point, were Scotland to become a pioneer in putting a fairer society ahead of a more affluent one, this would represent nothing less than a second enlightenment. The inequalities in health and housing, education and attainment that are nakedly apparent all around us, are shaming for one of the wealthiest countries in the world. No matter how much those at the top make, or how vibrant our financial markets, poverty and desperate hardship for too many people persists. Itrsquos tempting to think that those who see GDP and similar indices as telling the whole story have also embraced the biblical creed that the poor will always be with us ndash in other words, there is nothing we can do about their plight.While the SNP has not been far-sighted or proactive enough to combat the recent shocking rise in drug-related deaths, many of them linked to deprivation and hopelessness, nevertheless Ms Sturgeon and the like-minded leaders with whom she is allied, have a strong social conscience. If the message that money is only part of the equation takes hold, it could potentially prove a turning point for the way all rich societies see, and regulate, themselves.Naturally therersquos a danger when writing disparagingly about high-income earners of appearing either green-eyed or preachy. Despite spending a childhood in the pews, hearing how the widowrsquos mite was as valuable as the millionairersquos cheque, and that those who are hard up today will be blessed with eternal treasures in the hereafter, I nevertheless know that no pair of rose-tinted spectacles can make a terrying bill, an unattainable holiday or too-expensive winter coat, one bit easier to bear. As Mae West put it bluntly: ldquoIrsquove been rich and Irsquove been poor, and rich is better.When it comes to wellbeing, you donrsquot need a carbon monoxide monitor to recognise that the air in Stornoway or St Abbs is far better for us than that in the throbbing financial hearts of Edinburgh or Glasgow, or for that matter Tokyo and New York. Wellbeing consists of something way beyond liquidity, location, or assets. Those in their gated communities, who store their Cartier watches in a vault, have cut themselves off from the rest of society. Is that really enviable  This is not to say they might not be really decent, kind-hearted people who give generously to good causes. Perhaps some of them are. But no matter how open-handed they appear to be, money creates a spiralling gulf between the haves and the have-nots, and sometimes cause rts much closer to home, as family lawyers will attest.Far from solving the problem by capitalistsrsquo pet theory of ldquotrickle-down, too much capital at the top of society actually entrenches inequality. Thus, the endless pursuit of higher incomes, pricier properties, competitive conspicuous consumption, whether at a personal or national level, is intrinsically unhealthy. Once you believe that the GDP graph should show an inexorable year-on-year increase, you become blinkered. This is as true, I suspect, for those running the country as for the inidual.Hunger for amassing hundreds of thousands of pounds, and the power that comes with it, is a recipe for potential disaster. It is psychologically and spiritually corrosive. Slowing the Gradgrind pursuit of ever-greater productivity, focusing on more nourishing and longer-lasting priorities, is a way of calling time on the fallacy that the bottom line is all that matters, and that cash is king. It is a way of taking an ethical stance, and saying enough is enough. How to calculate what constitutes enough, of course ndash be it income, savings, love, leisure, charity, you name it ndash is even harder than measuring happiness.Read more: Scotlands history has lain in the British shadow for too long

title: scotland-39-s-newest-party-leader-swaps-big-top-political-circus
story: When not working full-time as an engineer, Lorna Slater mdash the new co-leader of the Scottish Greens mdash can be found flying through the air on a trapeze.The -year-old even trained with Aerial Edge, Glasgowrsquos circus school, for four months last year.As she puts it: ldquoYou canrsquot worry about politics or work when yoursquore hanging upside down by one hand.Ms Slater and long-standing MSP Patrick Harvie were elected co-leaders of the Scottish Greens last week, and will lead the party into the crucial  Holyrood polls.Both have put the climate emergency centre stage, while Brexit and independence also loom large.Speaking to The Herald following her election, Ms Slater outlined the balancing act of priorities the party now faces.And she also revealed her unusual way of letting off steam ndash sparked by flying trapeze lessons she was given for her th birthday.ldquoTo me the most important issue is the climate emergency, but unfortunately, with Brexit and all that, we have to swim in the waters that we find ourselves in, she said.ldquoSo we canrsquot ignore Brexit. Itrsquos whatrsquos on peoplersquos minds. I think wersquore going to have to try and ride both those horses ndash keep pressing on the climate emergency, keeping pushing the SNP Government to do more, because they declare a climate emergency and do nothing, and equally keep clear what our positive vision is for an independent Scotland in the EU.ldquoThe Unionist parties donrsquot have anything positive to say. Itrsquos all gloom and misery.ldquoThey tell this really miserable story about what the Union means post-Brexit, and I just donrsquot think you can win like that. You win by telling a positive story.An electromechanical engineer working in the renewable sector, Ms Slater was born in Canada and has previously been a Green candidate for Edinburgh Council and the European Parliament.She plans to stand for the Scottish Parliament and told activists she will be a ldquohands-on campaigner and organiser. Lothian MSP Alison Johnstone will continue to co-lead the Greens at Holyrood alongside Mr Harvie.Ms Slater said her primary goal is to help the Greens win more seats, with a particular focus on women and non-binary people.And she appeared keen to put clear green water between her party and the SNP.She dismissed suggestions the two parties should co-ordinate on independence in their next manestos, but made clear policies are for members to decide.She also rejected the idea of the Greens ndash who have propped up the last three budgets under the minority SNP administration ndash entering into any formal Holyrood coalition with the Nationalists in future.ldquoThe only issue we have in common with the SNP is independence, she said.ldquoOn everything , we tend to vote dferently from them. They vote with the Tories we vote with Labour.ldquoSo I think that that would actually be a terrible idea. It would be a terrible idea because we would end up signing up to policies that we donrsquot agree with at all.ldquoI think where we are right now is quite a good position to be in, where we can push the SNP on issues that matter to us, but we are not signed up to things that we really donrsquot agree with.Ms Slater said the SNP had failed ldquomiserably on land reform, and had left power ldquoin the hands of developers and big corporations and landowners.And she insisted the Nationalists ldquohave to finally pull their finger out on council tax.She added: ldquoThey have promised in manesto after manesto to reform it, and they keep not doing it. This is a very regressive tax. It would make a huge dference to public services.ldquoThey canrsquot keep complaining that Westminster is imposing this austerity on us when they themselves are not bold enough to reform that council tax.ldquoSo, for me, thatrsquos really important. As is taking action on this climate emergency that theyrsquove declared, and then havenrsquot done anything about.ldquoThey cannot continue to support grouse shooting and the fossil fuel industry and expanding the roads and so on. If therersquos a climate emergency, either there is or there isnrsquot.Asked about her passions outside of politics, Ms Slater revealed she trains with the circus, developing her skills on the flying trapeze and aerial silks. ldquoItrsquos just a hobby, she said, sparked by that gt almost four years ago.Still, with the new Scottish Green leaders elected for a two-year term, during a period of unprecedented political upheaval, there will be a lot to juggle. Circus skills could come in handy.

title: revealed-scottish-greens-lost-30-members-since-indyref-rise
story: The pro-independence party had over , members in the year after the independence referendum, but the total has fallen to below ,.The Greens were a key part of the Yes campaign during the  referendum and enjoyed an unprecedented surge in membership after the vote.:Scottish Greens elect Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater as co-leadersAt the start of , the party had , members, but this jumped to , by December , with income also rising.An analysis of party accounts reveals there has been a steady drop since that point. The figure fell to to , in  and dropped to , twelve months later.The most up-to-date number was released last week after the party announced the result of their leadership contest, when Harvie and former election candidate Lorna Slater were unveiled as co-leaders.There were , ldquoeligible voters in the contest, which the party confirmed is also the current membership total. This translates as a decrease of around % since .Only  votes were cast in the internal election, which works out as a turnout of .%. By contrast, the recent Tory and Liberal Democrat leadership contests were marked by turnouts of .% and % respectively.A party source countered by saying the number of members had increased in every month in , adding that more iniduals than ever before are also providing donations.However, critics believe the membership slump and low turnout reflect badly on a party they believe has lost its identity at Holyrood.Harvie and his colleagues are the kingmakers in the Parliament and have helped approve budgets proposed by the SNP Government.The Greens have been accused of selling themselves short, such as during the last Budget talks when they agreed to back the Governments tax and spending proposals in exchange for councils having to right to levy a workplace parking charge.Labour MSP Neil Findlay said: "We constantly hear sanctimonious guff from Patrick Harvie, who lectures everyone and anyone about democracy. Then we learn about the internal democracy of the Scottish Greens, where a whopping .% of members took part in their contest. Its hardly a vote of confidence in the new leadership."Tory MSP Murdo Fraser said: ldquoIt is extraordinary that, at a time when Green parties across Europe are surging in popularity, the exception is in Scotland where they have shedded members over the last four years. Perhaps the new leadership should reflect on what their priority should be: environmental politics, or just propping up the SNP Government and demanding another independence referendum.:A second referendum is the only route to independence, says Patrick HarvieA Scottish Greens spokesperson said: "The Scottish Greens have a dynamic young membership, most of whom have joined since  to take action on climate change. Before the independence referendum, the Scottish Greens had only , members, and this year we have seen a steady increase of new members join.""The party recognises we now need to give members more opportunities to get engaged and involved in the way the party works, which is one of the reasons our new co-leader Lorna Slater was elected. Lorna stood on a  of empowering and engaging with our grassroots members."

title: paul-hutcheon-no-deal-brexit-union-increasingly-incompatible
story: If the UK crashes out of the EU on October , tarfs will likely apply to imports and exports, and a recession will hover like a radioactive cloud.The economy, experts predict, will shrink and unemployment will increase. Rising food prices, particularly on products from the EU, will hit those of modest means. Do not fall ill in a hard Brexit Britain. A stockpile of medicines would dwindle and rationing may become inevitable. Waiting times could be introduced for prescriptions.:Revealed: Scottish Greens have lost % of their members since indyref riseOthers believe no deal will be a middle-class nightmare. House prices could fall by % and rates for savers may tumble to laughably low rates. Do not expect a handsome idend from your shares in UK companies.Escaping the UK for a holiday in Europe would almost certainly become an expensive and frustrating endeavour. Sterling would be weak and British motorists would be expected to produce a blizzard of paperwork simply for driving in the EU. The European Health Insurance Card , which guarantees healthcare in member states, would no longer apply. Stump up, Monsieur.No matter that it says to the contrary, large sections of the country feel Boris Johnsonrsquos Government does not care about the consequences of no deal, an outcome that will be triggered unless he extracts improbable concessions from European partners he has insulted. For the Prime Minister, leaving the EU is about politics, not economics.We have seen this movie before. David Cameron caved in to his party on an EU referendum because he saw it as the only way to unite his warring colleagues. Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit ldquored lines, which hampered her ability to secure any deal that could be approved by Parliament, were designed to keep the Tories together. Johnsonrsquos Brexit strategy is about ensuring the Conservatives stay in office.He knows his party cannot win another election until Brexit is delivered. The European poll, where the Brexit Party ided the Right, proved it. Last weekrsquos by-election in Brecon and Radnorshire, where the Tories lost by less than the votes polled by Nigel Faragersquos new outfit, confirmed Johnsonrsquos problem.An added complication is that the Brexit Party will not accept anything less than a hard Brexit. A tweaked version of Mayrsquos draft withdrawal agreement will lead to cries of betrayal and Farage and co standing in elections. Jeremy Corbyn, or new Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson, would be the beneficiary.Johnsonrsquos October  deadline ndash ldquodo or die ndash is about being able to say to voters at a snap general election that the country has left the EU in such a manner that satisfies the Brexit Party. Johnson would lose hundreds of thousands of votes to the LibDems, for sure, but he clearly believes this depletion would be offset by Farage leaving the pitch.No deal would be disastrous for the country economically, but the Tories could survive electorally by playing a familiar tune. Rising prices and falling living standards would be blamed on obstructionist Brussels. Nationalism always requires a bogeyman and the EU, as ever, would be the fall guy.A more signicant risk from Johnsonrsquos political standpoint would be the effect of no deal on his party in Scotland, and the Union. Leaving the EU without a contract is Ruth Davidsonrsquos worst nightmare. She would be pilloried by Nicola Sturgeon over the economic damage done to Scotland. Davidsonrsquos chances of becoming the next First Minister would fall from % to zero overnight.:Boris Johnson warned over possible resignations after by-election defeatDavidson, who is appalled by the prospect of no deal, is already feeling the pressure internally. A survey of Tory members by Conservative Home, an influential party blog, found that her approval rating was as high as % after the  election. But opposing Johnson has carried a cost. Her rating last week slumped to %.No deal is also likely to fuel support for Scottish independence, an outcome that observers of politics north of the Border may find ironic. It was Alex Salmond who, at the height of the referendum campaign in , suggested that an independent Scotland would refuse to pay its share of the UK debta currency union was turned down. He was flagging up a ldquono deal indy in all but name.Johnson is in a bind. If he fails to secure an acceptable Brexit, his party will implode. If he succeeds, leaving one political union will put another at risk. A no-deal Brexit and the Union look increasingly incompatible. The Prime Ministerrsquos new Cabinet seems more enthusiastic about delivering the former than protecting the latter.

title: snp-westminster-leader-calls-cross-party-summit-stop-no-deal-brexit
story: In his letter to the Westminster party leaders Ian Blackford said: "Time is short and we must act to prevent the Prime Minister destroying the futures of citizens up and down the country."He wrote to Labours Jeremy Corbyn, Plaid Cymrus Liz Saville Roberts, the Liberal Democrats Jo Swinson, Caroline Lucas from the Greens, and Anna Soubry from the Independent Group for Change, calling on them to "coalesce against a no-deal Brexit" and the "unmitigated damage" it will cause.He warned the risk of leaving the EU without a deal has increased after new Prime Minister Boris Johnson refused to rule it out.Blackfords call for an urgent summer recess meeting follows Chancellor Sajid Javids announcement of an additional pound. billion for no-deal planning.The SNP MP said: "The past three years of Tory Brexit chaos has pushed Scotland and the UK to the brink, and with Boris Johnson ramping up the rhetoric of a no-deal exit there is a very real risk of being pushed over the clf edge."We know that any Brexit - particularly a no-deal Brexit - will cause unmitigated damage to our economy and peoples living standards."Time and time again economic analysis has shown that Brexit will be devastating for businesses and public services. The evidence has shown the economic madness of Brexit."Rather than acting to prevent such an outcome, the Tory Prime Minister has instead chosen to push ahead by wasting billions of pounds of taxpayers cash on an entirely avoidable policy - at the same time as public services are still bearing the pain of Tory austerity."Blackford highlighted Scottish Government analysis suggesting leaving without a deal will cost Scots the equivalent of pound, each in reduced GDP and independent economic research forecasting , Scottish jobs being lost in this scenario.He added: "This cannot go on. I have written to the Westminster party leaders of Labour, Lib Dems, Plaid Cymru, Greens, and the Independent Group for Change, calling for a cross-party summit over summer recess to prevent the Prime Minister destroying the livelihoods of citizens across the UK, and move forward with efforts to take no-deal off the table."Meanwhile, the new Scottish Secretary has said the UK Government wants more of a say on how money to replace EU funding after Brexit is spent in Scotland.Alister Jack said the Shared Prosperity Fund, being set up in the place of EU structural funds, will brand projects it pays for with the union flag.Details of the new fund have not been finalised but Jack told the Scottishthat UK ministers would want to agree how the money would be spent with the Scottish Government.He denied the funding arrangements would be a power grab and said it would instead be a "collaboration".However, the SNP has accused him of "actively side-lining the country he is supposed to stand up for by aiding and abetting renewed attempts at a blatant Tory power grab - undermining the very foundations of devolution".Currently, the UK Government has been allocated pound. billion of EU structural investment between  and , which ministers have guaranteed to deliver post-Brexit.Under EU membership, the UK and EU sign a partnership agreement on the direction of the programmes, which are aimed at cutting disparity between EU regions, but the Scottish Government has responsibility for how the money is spent in Scotland.Jack told the newspaper: "We will be wanting to agree spending proposals and have more direct investment into Scotland."Rather than leaving the Scottish Government to "get on with it", it is believed future funding could be based on shared, specic goals."Its branding the spending of that money - rather than with the EU flag and a saltire, we will have the union flag and a saltire," he added."Its just important that the people see the benefits from being part of the great enduring partnership that is the United Kingdom."The SNPs Scotland Office spokesman, Tommy Sheppard, said: "Alister Jack has been Secretary of State for Scotland for only  days and already he is actively side-lining the country he is supposed to stand up for by aiding and abetting renewed attempts at a blatant Tory power grab - undermining the very foundations of devolution."Calls to bypass the Scottish Parliament and Government and instead allow the Tory Government to decide whats best for the people of Scotland rips up the established principles underpinning devolution."

title: scottish-labour-leadership-accused-quot-empty-words-quot-second-brexit-referendum
story: Richard Leonard and Lesley Laird have talked of a new vote sparingly in press releases since the Scottish party backed another vote, while at the same time blasting a no-deal Brexit on nearly  occasions.A party source said parliamentarians and activists were getting ldquoincreasingly frustrated at the stance adopted by the leadership.:Four in  Labour members back Scottish independence, poll findsOn Leonardrsquos watch, Scottish Labour slumped to fth place in the European elections after a campaign that was widely viewed as disastrous. The leaderrsquos colleagues believed Labour was punished for being ambiguous on a second referendum, while parties that were unequivocally in favour of another vote made gains.Leonard, a left winger, was accused after the election of copying the policy adopted by his ally Corbyn, who has not been an enthusiastic supporter of another Brexit vote.Recognising the scale of the defeat, Leonard promised to change his approach and he persuaded his party on June  to back a second vote on any Brexit deal.ldquoI am pleased that Scottish Labourrsquos Executive Committee has endorsed my call for the party to back a confirmatory vote on any Brexit deal with Remain as an option on the ballot paper, he said at the time. ldquoScottish Labour will wholeheartedly campaign for a Remain victory in such a vote.However, although Leonard repeated his support for a second vote  hours later, The Herald on Sunday could find no examples of him repeating this phrase in any press release since that point.In late June, in the context of Boris Johnsonrsquos Tory leadership bid, he hit out at a no-deal Brexit and said Scottish Labour was committed to standing up for the UKrsquos ldquoplace in Europe, but did not mention a referendum. An identical form of words was used on July  ndash when Johnson became Tory leader ndash where he also blasted no deal twice.Although Leonard flagged up his partyrsquos support for a ldquoconfirmatory vote on Twitter on the day of the policy change, he has not mentioned it since on the social media .The same analysis found one example of Laird, who is Corbynrsquos shadow Scottish Secretary and Leonardrsquos number two, mentioning ldquoconfirmatory vote in a press release after June . She referred to no deal around  times in the same period.:Scottish Labour leader: a doctor on pound, a year is working classIn a summer blog, Laird sounded downbeat about voters having another say on Brexit: ldquoWith Parliament in gridlock I have expressed my fears that there were signicant challenges for Parliament to overcome to be able to deliver a confirmatory vote. Sadly, my fears were borne out, and no consensus was found ... With Parliament unable to reach agreement, a confirmatory vote, I believe, is a way to try and break the impasse.ldquoBut with new Prime Minister Boris Johnson looking increasingly set to embrace a no-deal Brexit, the prospects do not look good, as by simply doing nothing he can run down the clock and crash us out of the European Union.A Scottish Labour source said: ldquoWe were told there had been a decisive change in policy following the European election, but so far it appears it was nothing but empty words. There has been no push to explain to the public that wersquore unambiguously a pro-remain party, and MSPs, MPs and activists knocking on doors are getting increasingly frustrated.Liberal Democrat MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton said: ldquoScottish Labour is being punished for its garbled position on Brexit because the public can see straight through their attempt to play both sides. Liberal Democrats are campaigning ferociously for a peoplersquos vote so the public can have the final say on Brexit. Wersquore the only party that is both pro-UK and pro-EU.SNP MSP Tom Arthur said: ldquoRichard Leonardrsquos conversion to the anti-Brexit cause appears to have lasted around as long as any of the partyrsquos many other positions.ldquoThe fact is, Labourrsquos position on Brexit is as clear as mud ndash mired in contradiction, confusion and obfuscation.Leonard told The Herald on Sunday: ldquoScottish Labourrsquos policy is clear, we need a confirmatory vote on any Brexit deal with a Remain option on the ballot paper. Scottish Labour will wholeheartedly campaign for a Remain victory in such a vote.ldquoSince Boris Johnson became Prime Minister the threat of there being a no-deal Brexit has drastically increased. A no-deal Brexit would be completely catastrophic for industry, for the economy and for people across Scotland, so it is also right that we unashamedly fight against it.

title: herald-sunday-diary-dope-tests-mascot-trials-radiation-sickos-something-myles-better
story: The Scottish professional football calendar kicked off yesterday, and for any players who are drug cheats or recreational users therersquos good news ndash the chances of being caught are vanishingly small. To call the drug testing programme tokenistic is a wild over-exaggeration. Itrsquos almost non-existent.According to the latest figures for the first three months of this year from UKAD, the anti-doping authority, there were just  Scottish players tested in competition. If the concentration was on the Premiership, which it almost certainly was, then that spanned at least  games involving more than , playerswhich, by my rudimentary maths, means the chance of even being tested was about one in , never mind getting caught.Of course the testing programme is meant to cover all four isions, or  teams, but I doubtthe testers turn up on a wet Wednesday in Brechin, so Irsquove kept the analysis to our top league, otherwise there would be considerably more chance of being hit by lightning than caught out.By contrast, in England a player in the Premier League can expect to be tested four times over the season, in the Championship marginally less. The four English leagues comprise  teams, with Scottish numbers at just under half that. For the quarter in England there were  in-competition tests, so a Scottish equivalent should have been around  ... six times the actual number.The drug authorities stress another key to catching out cheats is out-of-competition testing. In Scotland there were just , in England . But donrsquot imagine that the testers turn up at the door without warning at ungodly hours, as they do in athletics and tennis for instance. No, ours are done at training sessions and there is anecdotal evidence that testersrsquo targets are sometimes leaked in advance.Overall there were  tests carried out and paid for by the English FA in the quarter, , in the year, whereas in Scotland, for the SFA, the comparable totals were , and just . So the FArsquos testing is more than  times the rate of ours.Irsquove heard a range of excuses from the SFA, such as itrsquos too expensive, drugs donrsquot improve footballersrsquo performance and, equally risible, therersquos no evidence of cheating. No excrement Sherlock!I asked UKADthey believed that the SFA was carrying out adequate testing. Interpreting a rather circuitous response from the organisation, itrsquos the case that there is a basic public interest and intelligence-led programme, but the FA provides additional funds for a premium service, whereas it is clear the SFA does not, and this accounts for the yawning disparity.Mascot or mas-notThe place is hoachinrsquo with World Cups. Today, at the O in London, the Fa eWorld Cup concludes with the football game winner netting just over pound,. Of course, Scotland isnrsquot represented. We stand a better chance ndash or at least did at the time of writing ndash at the World Cup of Football Mascots where, in the semi-final, Partick Thistlersquos Kingsley was holding a slender lead over Super Pepino, from Spainrsquos Leganeacutes. The contestants donrsquot actually compete on a field, but in the ether. Itrsquos done by votes.It seems like football clubs are competing to come up with the most naff and excruciating mascot. In the other semi-final is West Bromwichrsquos Boiler Man who is, yes, a combi with legs. Itrsquos a sponsorship deal. On Friday Wigan unveiled their new, half-baked one, Crusty the Pie. Not that wersquove got anything to be superior about. Forfarrsquos is a giant bridie.Very craftyPeople think Boris Johnson is an eccentric buffoon who thinks with his mouth, but hersquos a lot more sophisticated and devious than that, with the rumpled suits, tousled hair, stuttering delivery and arm waving just part of the act. Take his bizarre, and apparently rambling, answer to a radio interviewer recently when he was asked how he relaxed. He made models of London buses, he replied, from old crates and wine boxes, with painted-on happy people. The assumption was that he was making it up, that he was caught out and was just uttering the first thing that came into his head. But perhaps not.Prior to this anyone going to Google and entering ldquoBoris bus would have been inundated with items about how he promised pound million to the NHS after Brexit, photographed as he stood in front of a red bus with that slogan ldquowe send the EU poundm a week on the side. And his failed attempt to reintroduce the Routemaster bus to London.But after his ldquoconfession, lo and behold, most of the unfavourable stuff had been pushed well down the pecking order by Borisrsquos alleged hobby. Itrsquos called SOE, or search engine optimisation, and itrsquos just the kind of wheeze Dominic Cummings, architect of Vote Leave, would have come up with. He hadnrsquot officially started as Borisrsquos senior adviser then, but there is the phone and email.A million MylesIrsquove been binge-watching Keeping Faith, the second series of which is on BBC. Forget the plot, itrsquos unmissable simply for the actor who plays the lead, Faith, Eve Myles. Her performance is electric, mesmerising, utterly convincing, with the complete emotional range, from joy ndash although therersquos not a lot of it ndash to sadness, anger and boredom, therersquos even a dash of fisticuffs from her as well. Myles is a boxing fan, and displays great technique, but she gave up participating when she broke a knuckle punching a wet sandbag, rather than an errant husband. I canrsquot remember seeing such a brave and bravura turn from an actress in, well, ever.Credit, too, to the producer, director and co-writer Pip Broughton for the casting, everyone in the show is top notch. She comes from a theatre background and in the series uses lots of close-ups of the charactersrsquo faces and emotions, so therersquos not much room for wooden acting. What is also unusual is that children in it arenrsquot just props, passed off to suit the plot, but central to Faithrsquos le, so family is at the heart, and heartache, of it. The show is scripted, but there are no rehearsals, with the actors pitched straight in to capture spontaneity.I looked up the -year-oldrsquos CV, shersquos been in Doctor Who and Torchwood ndash but which actor hasnrsquot  ndash but in productions mainly down the cast order. Not anymore. A couple of caveats. The villain has had a head transplant between series. And Faith has dodgy taste in men.X-ray specsUntil the mid-s it was common in shoe shops to test fittings by sticking your feet into an X-ray contraption called a fluoroscope, so you could look down the long tube to seethe skeletal bones in your feet had enough wiggle room. It wasnrsquot asthe dangers of radioactivity werenrsquot known, but after the sicknesses and cancers emerged in those who had witnessed, close-up, the atomic bomb tests in the , use of the Pedoscope was banned. Today we may have warped feet but at least we donrsquot rattle.It was Marie Curie and her husband Pierre who coined the word ldquoradioactive. Marie was quite cavalier about handling the sources, stuffing bottles of polonium and radium into her coats and jackets. If you want to see her papers ndash even her cookbooks ndash at Frances Bibliotheque National you have to get into moon suit and sign a waiver before you can open the lead lined boxes storing them. In  Pierre tied a chunk of radium to his arm and, noting the resultant burn, concluded he had discovered a cure for cancer.Manufactures then stuffed their products with radioactive thorium and advertised the supposed health benefits. Radium bath salts claimed to treat insomnia. Pots and jugs lined with radon and uranium were prescribed for flatulence.Of course, we donrsquot believe this nonsense nowadays. Well, not quite. Thousands of people each year, from around the world, travel to four former uranium mines in Montana to pay to sit in radioactive mine shafts, believing that being exposed to radon gas can cure their ailments, or at least mitigate pain. The theory is that exposure to low-dose radiation, while it damages cells, prompts compensatory processes that stimulate repair, decrease free radicals, and activate proteins that prevent inflammation. No, I donrsquot know what that means either.In the centre of it all is Butte, Montana ndash with its wonderfully-named bar called Pisserrsquos ndash a town of , people built on a honeycomb of old copper mines, and probably the most radioactive populated place in world, with radon gas leaking into homes. Many of the old houses are built from bricks made from phosphate slag, large portions of the town are paved with it. No surprise the lung cancer rate is getting on for double the national average.

title: last-man-standing-president-putin-world-39-s-leaders-for-life
story: Some are household names, others less so or even quite obscure. So herersquos a question for your next pub quiz. What do Russian president Vladimir Putin and Teodoro Obiang Nguema, president of Equatorial Guinea, have in common Well, to begin with, excluding monarchs, they are both among some of the world leaders who have held power the longest.This weekend, -year-old president Obiang will have been in power for a staggering  years, a record time for any sitting president in the world.You have to go all the way back to August , , to mark the day that Obiang overthrew his uncle, the dictator Francisco Macias Nguema, who was shot two months later. In the intervening decades, Obiang claims to have foiled at least  coups or assassinations against him, all the time accusing the countryrsquos army, political opposition or foreign powers.Vladimir PutinIn that same period, Obiangrsquos rule of Equatorial Guinea has often been cited by human rights groups such as Amnesty International as one where repressive measures including torture, extra-judicial executions, arbitrary arrests, and the persecution of political activists and human rights defenders is commonplace.:Pictures: Hundreds more arrested in Russian pro-democracy protestsOil-rich Equatorial Guinea is also one of the most corrupt countries in the world, a place where Obiangrsquos cohorts in power have a penchant for investing in luxury private mansions in Europe rather than helping rid the country of its widespread poverty.By comparison to Obiang, as world leaders go, Putin is a new kid on the block, evenhis time in the Kremlin is fast approaching  years. Yes, it really has been that long since the steely president stepped into the Kremlin and the world sat up and took notice.Earlier this year, after almost three decades in power, an autocratic neighbour of Putin, Kazakhstanrsquos president Nursultan Nazarbayev, himself one of the last political survivors of the former Soviet Union, finally resigned, effectively taking him off what has sometimes in derisory terms been dubbed the ldquoleaders for le list.Nursultan NazarbayevFollowing the stepping down of Nazarbayev, and with Algerian president Abdelaziz Bouteflikarsquos decision to end his re-election bid and the fall of Sudanrsquos Omar al-Bashir in the face of mass protests, perhaps now is as good a time as any to examine just what it is that helps keep such leaders in power for so long.Currently, according to the independent watchdog organisation Freedom House, which monitors freedom and democracy around the world, the  or so longest-serving leaders in the world all represent countries considered ldquonot free by the organisationrsquos criteria.The fact the first  of these leaders are also men speaks volumes about the ways in which global political structures remain weighted.Indeed, itrsquos not until number  on the list that one comes across what is deemed a ldquofree country, or indeed a female leader, in this case Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.In an arena where political power is slippery and can vanish with one wrong move, what is it that helps keep the longest-serving leaders in place Angela MerkelldquoAt the very essence of it is the hunger for continued power, says Anneke Van Woudenberg, who as a former director of the Africa Division of Human Rights Watchspent years monitoring and researching the role of many leaders on a continent home to half of the  longest-serving leaders and five of the top seven.But as well as the human desire for authority and prestige, Van Woudenberg points to other purely practical factors at play in preventing many leaders, especially in Africa, from standing down willingly or gracefully.ldquoRetiring as a head of state in Africa doesnrsquot usually come with a lot of benefits, Van Woudenberg, who is now executive editor of the organisation Rights and Accountability in Development, told Newsweek.ldquoVery few African countries ndash in fact almost none ndash have any kind of pension or security scheme for former presidents or heads of state. So out of power means out of money.In Africarsquos case, ever since the turn of the st century the trend of entrenched leadership had spread across the region. In its wake it often spurred corruption, instability, social ision and economic stagnation. While that trend might now show signs of reversing, it persisted for a iety of reasons.As a recent study by the US-based international affairs think tank the Council on Foreign Relationsconcluded, many of Africarsquos leaders increasingly secured longer terms through ldquoconstitutional coups, proposing amendments for approval by the legislature or judiciary, or in national referendums, that allowed for additional terms in office.Around the year , when many post-colonial leaders were nearing the ends of their constitutional term limits, this pattern became more distinct. Since then, says CFR,  heads of state have tried to remain in power by adjusting their countriesrsquo constitutions.Among them was Namibian president Sam Nujoma in , followed by Gnassingbe Eyadema, the president of Togo, in . One year later, the Gabonese parliament voted to remove term limits from its constitution, allowing president to run for a sixth term.David Cameron and deposed Algerian strongman Abdelaziz BouteflikaThis quickly became regular practice every few years in African nations as widespread as Angola, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cameroon, Chad, Djibouti, Equatorial Guinea, Guinea, Niger, Nigeria, the Republic of Congo, Rwanda, Senegal, Sudan and Uganda.Another reason for Africarsquos recurring third-term problem is the lack of effective political opposition in many countries, say analysts.ldquoThe opposition to these constitutional changes comes from inside, says Phil Clark, lecturer in comparative international politics at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London.ldquoIt tends to come from domestic oppositions, rather than the African Union or regional powers or international donors.Clark goes on to cite Rwanda as one example, which, although widely considered a one-party state, has several opposition parties, though none offers a credible challenge to current president Paul Kagamersquos Rwandan Patriotic Front .Should some opposition parties ever pose a threat to the status quo, many African governments and leaders think nothing of quashing their challengers. In the past, military coups were common as a means to seize power, with both Equatorial Guinearsquos president Obiang and his Ugandan counterpart Yoweri Museveni entering their presidencies this way.In all, in Africa, there were  successful coups from  to , but only  from  to , and just the one ndash against Zimbabwersquos ndash since then, according to CFR analysis.It would be very wrong to single out Africa as the sole region where the rulers of countries have held on to power for long periods through nefarious or authoritarian means.From Latin America to Europe and the Middle East to Asia, there are many examples of those who qualy in the leaders-for-le stakes. At their disposal is a ied bag of political strategies and tricks.A small number of rulers stays in office, of course, simply by ignoring the letter or spirit of the law. Some veteran leaders, as Freedom House points out, simply reset the clock, evading time limits by arguing that the restrictions in new constitutions do not apply retroactively.Others use what has been called a ldquolegislative assist, among them Kazakhstanrsquos president Nazarbayev, who as far back as  used a loyalist legislature to push through constitutional amendments that exempted him ndash and only him, as the first president of independent Kazakhstan ndash from a two-term limit.Freedom House says other aspiring leaders-for-le have turned to referendums ndash riggednecessary ndash to extend their rule. The options are surprisingly ied, which brings us back to Putin.While it may seem a long way off, whether Putin retains power after , when his current term ends, is the key question of Russian politics today. The outcome will also have a major influence in shaping international affairs and policies.Robert MugabeAs Leonid Bershidsky, columnist with the media company Bloomberg, recently pointed out, constitutional limits in Russia ndash just as in parts of Africa ndash are not what they are in other places. In effect, the Kremlin controls the Russian parliament to an extent that makes it possible to change the constitution at any moment, making Putin president for le.ldquoThat lsquonuclear optionrsquo, however, is anathema to Putin, who, despite persistent election rigging in his favour, insists on democratic legitimacy as the basis for his rule, explained Bershidsky in an article last month.Like many Russia watchers, Bershidsky is intrigued by how none of the relatively legitimate scenarios for keeping Putin in power past  look comfortable to the Russian leader.The pressure on Putin has lately been compounded by increasing protests on the streets of Moscow challenging the government over the rejection of independent candidatesrsquo applications for the cityrsquos council elections.The Moscow protests are part of a trend of local demonstrations showing a growing defiant stance against Putinrsquos managed democracy.:Two autocrats deposed in a week in Sudan and AlgeriaOne Russian media outlet has even reported that the Kremlin believed the protests were being backed by foreign influences intent on starting a ldquocolour revolution, a reference to protests that have overturned governments in other post-Soviet republics.Even as Putin runs out of palatable options for prolonging his reign beyond the constitutional limits, Russian democrats know not to get their hopes up as he undoubtedly remains in charge.That said, as a New York Times editorial pointed out last week, leaders of post-Soviet states have typically lost their grip on power by making one of two big mistakes.The first is brazen manipulation of elections the second is official impunity ndash above all, brutality by law-enforcement agencies.ldquoFew things make people quite so mad, observed the NYT. ldquoThe so-called Rose Revolution in Georgia in , Orange Revolution in Ukraine in , and Tulip Revolution in Kyrgyzstan in  were all touched off by phony vote counts and other electoral fraud.Faced with such challenges to his ldquosoft dictatorship and desire to stay in power, Putin has only a few options. One might be to push for Russiarsquos merger with neighbouring Belarus.Such a manoeuvre would make it possible for Putin to head up the unied country.According to Bloomberg analysts, another would be for Putin to do what he did in , letting a dependable ally, Dmitry Medvedev, run for president and staying on as prime minister to sit out a presidential term as required by the constitution. and Prime Minister Vladimir Putin REUTERS Sergei Karpukhin" alt"HeraldScotland: Russias President Dmitry Medvedevand Prime Minister Vladimir Putin REUTERS Sergei Karpukhin" class"editor-image"Vladimir Putin and Dmitri Medvedev, when Mr Medvedev was presidentBut Putin these days has perhaps fewer people in the Kremlinrsquos inner circle that he can trust, unlike back then.Around the world, of course, not all leaders resort to unscrupulous or ruthless methods for their longevity.As Freedom House observes, ldquoin some cases, these rulers have earned their long tenures through relatively free elections and remained within constitutional bounds. In the vast majority, however, a single leader has stayed in power by abusing, weakening or completely overriding key democratic institutions.In many cases their long reigns begin to resemble those of kings and sultans. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, once described as the ldquoinventor of st-century populism, is a case in point.Yesterday, president Nguema of Equatorial Guinea marked  years in power. Evenhe should stand down, itrsquos said he has already been grooming his -year-old son Teodorin and his vice-president to take over the top job of the small oil state in central Africa.Certain leaders, it appears, find it near impossible to relinquish power completely. It was another African long-time ruler, former president Yahya Jammeh of the Gambia, who once declared he would rule for ldquoone billion yearsGod wills it, and that only God can set term limits. Some are only too willing to endorse that view.Worldrsquos longest-serving leadersApart from monarchs, who are usually installed for le, here are the leaders who have ruled for the longest:Leading the pack is Cubarsquos revolutionary hero Fidel Castro, with  years in power. When he handed over in , ill and aged in his early s, it was to his brother Raul.Taiwanrsquos first president Chiang Kai-shek was in charge on the island and in mainland China for  years until his death in .Fidel CastroNorth Korearsquos founder Kim Il-sung ran the reclusive state for  years before dying in office in , remaining revered as the ldquoeternal leader.Muammar Mohammed Gaddafi ruled Libya with an iron fist for almost  years before being ousted and then slaughtered in  by rebels at the height of the Arab Spring uprisings.Omar Bongo Ondimba governed oil-rich Gabon for more than  years until his death from cancer in .Albaniarsquos communist dictator Enver Hoxha was in power for  years until his death in .Still adding up their time at the top are:Cameroonrsquos president Paul Biya at  yearsCongo-Brazzavillersquos Denis Sassou Nguesso at  years, excluding a five-year pause after he lost a  electionCambodian prime minister Hun Sen,  yearsUgandarsquos president Yoweri Museveni,  yearsIranrsquos Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has been supreme leader since the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in  years and counting:Chadrsquos Idriss Deby Itno,  yearsTajikistanrsquos Emomali Rahmon,  yearsEritrearsquos Isaias Afwerki,  yearsBelarus Alexander Lukashenko,  yearsDjiboutirsquos Ismail Omar Guelleh,  yearsGabonrsquos Ali Bongo who will have been in power for  years in October

title: whaley-bridge-prepares-downpours-work-continues-fix-dam
story: Dozens more homes have been evacuated in Whaley Bridgeahead of expected bad weather on Sunday, as emergency workers continue their efforts toprevent the dam giving way.There remains athreat to le in the town and  further properties were cleared in theHorwich End area this weekend, on top of around ,residents who had already been evacuated.Water levels at the Toddbrook Reservoir in the town have been reduced by . metres since Thursday, the Department for the Environment said, but police warned the -year-old structure remained in a ldquocritical condition with a breach still a ldquovery real threat.:Dam still critical but Whaley Bridge residents allowed home to collect essentialsForecasters warned of the potential for up to mm of rain to fall in just an hour or two on Sunday afternoon.Speaking about the prospect of the evacuated people moving back in, he told BBC Breakfast: ldquoAt the rate we are pumping, we are hoping certainly towards the end of the week we be in a position to be able to do that.A Met Office yellow weather warning is in place for much of northern England and the Midlands, including the area around the reservoir.Meteorologist Mark Wilson said: ldquoThere is the potential for some thundery showers which could give some very unwelcome rain .ldquoThere is the potential for -mm in just one to two hours.Police said the added evacuations on Saturday evening were due to ldquoa potential increase in risk of adverse weather in coming days and the ongoing risk of the Toddbrook Reservoir breaching.A map of houses that have been evacuated from the Horwich End area of #WhaleyBridge has been produced: pic YczPVfIKmdash Derbyshire PoliceAugust , Residents evacuated on Thursday told how they grabbed medication and beloved pets when they were allowed to very brieflyhome on Saturday, having been warned by police they did so at their own risk.Reminding residents they should onlyfor essential items, Chief Superintendent Michelle Shooter said:ldquoI would like to take this opportunity to remind local residents that the state of the dam is still in a critical condition and that the risk of breach is still a very real threat.Joan Pass, , was in tears after she went back for the first time since the mass evacuation of the town, describing it as ldquoterrible.:Whaley Bridge reservoir dam feared to be near collapse facing lsquocriticalrsquo momentShe said she thought there had been an explosion when first told to evacuate.Mrs Pass said: ldquoThe bells were ringing ndash I didnrsquot know what the bells were ringing for. My daughter said get out, get your passport and your medication.ldquoI thought it was a bomb.Ben Pudsey and Andrew McNair, from Animal Search UK, said they had rescued a cockatiel called Joey from one of the evacuated houses, where he had escaped from his cage and was flying around the living room.Tracey Coleman said she, her -year-old daughter Anna and the rest of the family left on Thursday with their two dogs, a cat, a tortoise and the neighbourrsquos dog and went to her motherrsquos house nearby.:Dam still critical but Whaley Bridge residents allowed home to collect essentialsBoris Johnson visited the area on Friday and promised that the damaged reservoir would have a ldquomajor rebuild as he met locals at nearby Chapel-en-le-Frith High School.Environment Secretary Theresa Villiers, who visited the area on Saturday, paid tribute to the ldquopatience and fortitude of residents and thanked all those working to repair the dam.An RAF Chinook has dropped more than  sandbags, andaround  firefighters have been using high-volume pumps to removeexcess water from the reservoir.Residents are expected to be updated on the situation at a meeting on Sunday evening.The reservoir is on the north-west edge of the Peak District National Park and was built in , according to experts, although the Environment Agency records it as being built in -.

title: french-inventor-franky-zapata-celebrates-crossing-channel-hoverboard
story: Franky Zapatacompleted the feat in just  minutes on Sunday morning, landing in St Margarets Bay in Kent after taking off from Sangatte, near Calais.Speaking after he landed, the -year-oldsaid completing the challenge was the best moment of his le.Read more:-year-old Scot scales Everest foothillsHe said: "I just feel very happy. All my family, friends and my team were all behind me so I was so proud and so happy for them."It was just a very big emotion, the best moment of my le, I was very happy."Franky Zapata takes flight on his hoverboardDuring the flight, Mr Zapata largely stayed  feet above the water and told crowds that he reached speeds of up to km h .His hoverboard is powered by a backpack of kerosene which is able to keep him airborne for about  minutes, meaning he had to stop to refuel halfway through the journey.Last week, the former jet-ski champion failed in his first attempt at the -mile crossing after he crashed into a refuelling boat  miles into the flight.However, he was able to overcome this on Sunday by using a larger boat to make landing easier.Read more:Pioneering Scottish female archaeologist featured at new museumAsked how dficult it had been to complete the feat, he said: "It has been very dficult. Ive had six months of hard, physical training, and weve had to push the technology to the maximum to be able to fly fast for a long time."And last week was especially hard because we crashed and exploded the machine and we had to completely rebuild the machine."But today is really special. People ask my why I built it - I built it because I want to fly.Breaking into tears, he added: "We made a machine three years ago... and now weve crossed the Channel, its crazy."Whether this is a historic event or not, Im not the one to decide that, time will tell."Mr Zapata has been developing his hoverboard for the past three years, undeterred by losing two fingers in its turbines during its maiden flight in his garage near Marseille.The flyboard has five turbines and can reach speeds of up to mph .The inventor received widespread attention during the annual Bastille Day parade in Paris last month, when he took part in a military display on his futuristic board.Read more:Scottish adventurer becomes fastest woman to cycle around the worldFrances military has also sought to develop the technology for itself, and recently gave his company, Z-AIR, a euro.mgrant.In an interview with France Inter radio, French Defence Minister Florence Parly said the flyboard could serve several purposes, "for example as a flying logistical  or, indeed, as an assault ".Mr Zapata hopes his device will one day enter commercial production as a revolutionary piece of military hardware.

title: former-scottish-labour-minister-admits-party-39-small-irrelevant-39
story: Margaret Curran said the SNP were ldquolicking their lips at the state of Scottish Labour, which was ldquonow a small party in Scotland.She said: ldquoWe are not terribly relevant. We are not saying relevant things at the moment.Scottish Labour came fth in Mayrsquos European Election, losing both its MEPs and falling to less than  per cent of the vote.Its poll ratings have fallen sharply since Richard Leonard became Scottish leader in late .:Scottish Labour on le support and facing terminal declineSpeaking on BBC Radio Scotlandrsquos Good Morning Scotland, Ms Curran said Labour was no longer embedded in the fabric of communities in the way it had been in past decades.She said: ldquoI think the Scottish Labour party particularly - and the UK Labour party should look at our experience - but it has to come to terms with the fact that wersquore now a small party in Scotland.ldquo think we have to accept we are not that powerful party anymore. We have no right to it. We have to earn that right again.Referring to how Labour was once woven into Scotlandrsquos social fabric, she said: ldquoI remember the Labour clubs, the churches had a big connection, both the Church of Scotland and Catholic church, had a lot of Labour people within them. There was quite a lot of overlap. ldquoThatrsquos all gone. That has all completely gone. Thatrsquos just reality. You need to readjust.However she said Scottish Labour was still failing to reform itself,  years after losing power to the SNP in .She said a key lesson for parties was learning from defeat then undertaking internal reforms, however she ldquostruggled to think what reforms Scottish labour had had since .:Two-thirds of Labour voters fail to identy partys Scottish leaderShe said: ldquoI can think of reforms we did in government, but not reforms we introduced in the party.ldquoWersquove not done that and until we do that, we will not get routes back, we will not earn that right, we will not have that conversation with Scottish people.ldquoWersquore not terribly relevant. Wersquore not saying relevant things at the moment, I think.ldquoI think we can, and I think we have to, and I think therersquos a vacuum there for those things to be said, but wersquore not doing it.:Scottish Labour leadership accused of "empty words" on second Brexit referendumMs Curran, , was an MSP from  to  and a minister between  and .She was the MP for Glasgow East from  to  before losing her seat to the SNP.She is now an international trainer and consultant on political and womenrsquos affairs in Africa, the Middle East and Asia.She said she ldquonever had any hope for the ldquohard left faction who took over Labour under Jeremy Corbyn, but was still ldquogobsmacked by their failure to tackle anti-Semitism.A Scottish Labour spokesperson said:"Richard Leonard is ensuring that our organisation and operations are fully battle-ready.ldquoThis will give us the best possible chance to win again in Scotland, not for our own sake but for the sake of all those people in all of those communities who need a Scottish Labour government."

title: tory-party-chairman-wont-initiate-general-election
story: The Prime Minister was reported to be plotting for an election to boost his diminishing ranks in Parliament and increase his chances of getting a deal past MPs.His flurry of spending commitments, including a pound. billion NHS pledge on Sunday, have fuelled thinking that he is trying to woo voters.But chairman James Cleverly sought to rule out a national vote this year."There isnt. We are not going to initiate a general election," he said, when appearing on Skys Sophy Ridge On Sunday."What weve got is a new Prime Minister who during the leadership campaign made a number of explicit commitments and he is setting about delivering on those commitments."Prime ministers making good on their promises is a good thing and that is what we are doing."On top of the NHS spending, Mr Johnson has unveiled plans to hire , extra police officers and pledged pound. billion to increase no-deal preparations.He says a new Withdrawal Agreement is his preferred option for leaving the EU, but shepherding this through Parliament is becoming ever more challenging, evenhe can secure a deal from Brussels.This week his already slender working majority became just one when the Tories lost the Brecon and Radnorshire by-election.Theresa May failed three times to get her agreement through Parliament, and that was with the support of more MPs.One way to potentially improve his numbers would be for Mr Johnson to get about two thirds of MPs to support a motion for a general election.But he could rely on Labour trying to bring down his administration with a vote of no confidence, which could also bring about a national votea new government is not formed within a fortnight.Mr Johnson has made a "do or die" declaration to get the UK out of the bloc by the Halloween deadline, regardless of whether he has brokered a new deal or not.Former attorney general Dominic Grieve warned on Sunday that he could still quit the Tory party over no-deal.And Labour said it was working with MPs across the board to prevent the scenario.

title: third-water-pumped-whaley-bridge-reservoir
story: He said: "Emergency services, partner agencies and volunteers have continued to work tirelessly through the night to reduce the risk of the Toddbrook Dam failing."Crews have been faced with a massive challenge to pump water from the reservoir and this work continues. A total of  pumps have been working through the night and we have been successful in taking about % of the water held in the reservoir out."This work will continue until engineers are confident that the water is at a safe level and the risk has been mitigated."He said crews were working to bring the situation to the "quickest and most effective conclusion" and added: "Our priority remains the same, to pump as much water out of the reservoir as possible, to protect the Whaley Bridge community from the risk of the dam failing."People will not be allowed toto their homes on Sunday to collect vital items, Derbyshire Police said, amid a forecast of further heavy rain.The force said: "The decision has today, Sunday August , been taken to stop allowing evacuated residents back to their homes in Whaley Bridge. This is with immediate effect."The original decision was to allow residents to collect pets and urgent medication and other vital items."Residents and businesses were supported by officers throughout Friday evening and Saturday to enter their addresses for a brief and controlled period."The attention of officers and other responders has to be on the preservation of le and, while there was an urgent need over the past  hours to allow residents back into the area, our first duty is to protect the lives of the public and emergency services."Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn tweeted: "The emergency services and RAF have done a fantastic job in Whaley Bridge and the residents with the support of the wider community have pulled together wonderfully. The situation is very concerning and our solidarity goes out to the residents."Derbyshire Police tweeted: "The water level at Toddbrook Reservoir has been reduced by just over three metres. Pumps are continuing to remove water at a rate of around cm an hour. Once a level has been reached, engineers will view the damage and decideresidents  businesses can re-enter #WhaleyBridge.Deputy Chief Constable Rachel Swann added: said: The situation at the reservoir is still critical and the threat to le remains very high in Whaley Bridge and surrounding #GoytValley area. I want my officers to be able toto their families at the end of their shts, not be put in harms way."The spirit shown by the community has been absolutely fantastic. Volunteers are helping at the scene and for that we are enormously grateful."

title: ridge-sunday-review
story: Besides filming at dawn, Boyles team asked drivers nicelythey would not mind waiting a bit to cross the SE thoroughfare. Amazingly, most motorists agreed. Oh for those more innocent, less fractious, pre-Extinction Rebellion days.It helped enormously, of course, that it was summer and MPs and peers were on holiday. Westminster and Holyrood are ghost towns during recess, their corridors silent save for the noise of maintenance work. With no politicians around, normal political programming on television is suspended. So it was yesterday.These, however, are hardly normal times. The papers were crammed with reporting and analysis of Boris Johnsonrsquos first week as Prime Minister, and speculation over a General Election continued to mount. Plenty to keep the Sunday political programmes busy, but any viewer in search of ministerial answers was left to wander through the schedules like Cillian Murphy, crying out ldquoHello  Anyone there : Greens lose membersThere was one exception: Sky News had Ridge on Sunday. But even it was sans Sophy Ridge, with Scots presenter Niall Paterson standing in for the holidaying anchor.With a series of guests who would struggle to be household names outside their own front doors, the show made a good case for political programmes shutting up shop for the summer.The only news lines which emerged came from an interview with Conservative party chairman James Cleverly MP, who said the Government was not going to initiate a general election , and that the party would be setting up an independent inquiry into alleged Islamophobia within its ranks.Otherwise, Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth doubtless earned himself some Brownie points with the Labour press office for putting on a suit and tie on a Sunday and standing before the camera, but he added precious little to the national debate about Brexit or much .: Paul Hutcheon on a no deal BrexitAt one point Paterson askedit was the case, as had been reported, that MPs were now too late to stop a no deal Brexit. Mr Ashworth suggested speaking to the Number  aide who was said to have briefed along those lines, one Dominic Cummings. Oh, wersquove asked him to come on, Paterson chortled, but to no avail.Cummings would not accept such an invitation but plenty would ndash as long as it was during term time. Politics programmes stand or fall on the quality of their guests, andno-one is around that is another reason to pull the plug.Everyone deserves a break. Politicians, despite reforms to their working arrangements, still work unsocial hours, as do the men and women who cover them. Voters in general could do with hitting the pause button on politics. It is not just Brenda from Bristol who is sick of General Election talk.In any case, there may be no mainstream political programmes on, no Peston, no Question Time, no Marr, and the rest, but politics continues to be covered in newspapers, online, and on radio. So why the fuss Whatever  it does, the summer break raises questions about how politics is covered by broadcasters and whether methods are keeping up with the times. It has become accepted that readers, viewers and listeners want their news and analysis at a time and in a form that suits them. Most of the media has changed accordingly. The only major change in television, however, has been Pestons move from Sundays to midweek ndash a sht that has paid off.: SNP Westminster leader in call for summitPolitics coverage on television continues to revolve around big personalities. With so many sources of news, and when anyone can be their own broadcaster via social media, you might think TV political editors and commentators are among those ldquoexperts Michael Gove once dismissed as surplus to public requirement. Television does not think so.But does the quality of coverage and debate really suffer because Robert Peston is sipping Rose somewhere nice or Laura Kuenssberg is on a cruise  Are we not done with the days of expecting one all-seeing, all-knowing person to have all the answers There remains an assumption among broadcasters that viewers like to hear from a trusted voice, an inidual who can cut through the white noise and convey clearly what is going on. It is a big responsibility but that is supposedly why it comes with the big bucks. The BBCrsquos political editor Kuenssberg is paid between pound,-pound,, more than the PM and First Minister, and her commercial counterparts are thought to be on more.Then again, politics since the EU referendum has often seemed to be one long exercise in proving that screenwriter William Goldman was right when he said nobody knows anything.Do viewers really need or want yet more speculation from political editors  Perhaps they should go old school, like Danny Boyle on the set of  Days Later, and wait for things to happen before reporting on them. But how would   news fill all those hours then The fact remains that it is the stated policy of the British Government to leave the EU on October  with or without a deal. The clock is ticking.If this is not a time when Ministers need to supply answers to pressing questions it is hard to know when that might be.Broadcast coverage of politics since the EU referendum was one of peaks and troughs. Before and during the campaign it was wall to wall. After that, a strange silence descended, years passed, and suddenly Theresa May had a deal that needed she had to get through parliament. By the time problems surfaced there was no time to sort them out.Here we are today,  days to Brexit, and the same sense of denial is taking hold. It is quiet out there in TV land. Too quiet.

title: issue-day-anniversary-first-ad-slogan
story: What was the slogan August saw what is recognised as the worldrsquos first advertising slogan appear in print - ldquoBeechams Pills: Worth a Guinea a Box.They promised to ldquodislodge bile, stir up the liver, cure sick-headache, female ailments, remove disease and promote good health.And it, of course, cost less than a guinea to buy them.Beechams - as in the cold and flu remedy Thatrsquos what the Beechams name is now associated with, but in those days, the pills were marketed as a pick-me-up and became very popular with the British public as a general health booster.The British Medical Association investigated in  and found that they were actually a concoction of powdered soap, aloes and ginger - but sales continued apace.And they benefited from advertising The forward-thinking firm founder, Thomas Beecham, realised that a punchy slogan would grab attention. By , he spent pound, a year on advertising - an astonishing figure for the era. His heir, Joseph, spent  million in the US alone between  and .And other firms took note Carving out a slogan became the thing to do as firms realised that a catchphrase that grabs attention could be worth its weight in gold.Remind me of some famous ones Take your pick from a plethora of hits - although some have, of course, hit the spot better than others.Through the years, the most memorable include ldquoBeanz Meanz Heinz, ldquoOpal Fruits, made to make your mouth water, ldquoGuinness is good for you and ldquoDrinka pinta milka day.A Mars a day helps you work, rest and play Itrsquos a slogan often credited to racing commentator Murray Walker, but although he was involved with it as the then-account director for advertising firm Masius and Ferguson, he didnrsquot come up with it himself. It was coined by ad-man Francis Harmar Brown at the firm in .Any others that spring to mind Kentucky Fried Chickenrsquos ldquoFinger lickinrsquo good endures, as does the famous Cadburyrsquos Milk Tray line: ldquoAll because the lady loves Milk Tray.Other taglines that linger include ldquoHave a break...have a KitKat and British Railrsquos ldquoLet the train take the strain.ldquoAustralians wouldnrsquot give a XXXX for anything  was a hit for Castlemaine XXXX Beer in the s, while ldquoAh! Bisto dates back to .And what was the one about an egg One of the most famous slogans in history is easily the ldquoGo to work on an egg line, used by the United Kingdomrsquos Egg Marketing Board in the s and s as part of a campaign worth more than pound million, which included a series of TV adverts starring the comedian Tony Hancock and actress Patricia Hayes.The idea was that having an egg for breakfast was the best way to start the working day and author Fay Weldon is credited with having come up with the slogan that captured hearts with its wholesome simplicity.And how are Beechams faring In , a merger brought them into the GlaxoSmithKlinefold, with the Beechams name still used to sell over-the-counter cold and flu remedies as the brand endures.Nowadays, GSK are definitely worth more than a guinea and have an advertising budget of around . billion.

title: female-engineers-mission-get-girls-joining-profession
story: But women engineers still make up a tiny minority of the profession in the UK, which has the lowest percentage of female engineers in Europe.Now female engineering students in Scotland are helping to change that by encouraging more girls to follow in their footsteps.FemEng is a network for women in the School of Engineering at the University of Glasgow that goes into schools to talk about engineering, holds networking events with women industry professionals, and has international collaborations.Hannah Gibson, , a Biomedical Engineering student and outreach convenor for the society, said: ldquoEngineering is still a very male-dominated subject at the University and women today only make up  per cent of the UK engineering workforce.ldquoA lot of girls are put off going into engineering because they donrsquot see many women role models ndash as the saying goes,you canrsquot see it, you canrsquot be it.One of FemEngrsquos most important roles is to go into schools and show girls that women can be engineers, and that itrsquos a rewarding career.ldquoGirls are often put off STEMsubjects and we need to encourage more of them to take them up. I didnrsquot do Physics until I was studying for my Highers, so I had to do some catching up.ldquoGirls are put off engineering by its image as male and geeky. At one school talk, a pupil said she liked being a lsquogirly-girlrsquo and askedyou can wear make up and feminine clothes as an engineer. When I tell people Irsquom an engineering student, the response is often: lsquoOh, but you donrsquot look like an engineerrsquo.ldquoBy going into schools and being role models, we can break down these barriers. I recently ed from an outreach trip to Rwanda where we went into schools along with female engineering students from the University of Rwanda. A -year-old girl wrote to me later and told me I had impressed her and she wants to be like me.ldquoIn Scottish schools some girls are not interested, butIrsquom able to show one of them that itrsquos an option for the future, thatrsquos so rewarding.ldquoEngineering has an image problem but it is incredibly creative and does a lot of good in the world. As an engineer, you have a creative outlook on le, you want to improve things and make them more efficient. Engineering has a huge impact and can help disadvantaged communities.While women like Hannah are making inroads into engineering, there is still a long road to travel. Despite being one of the first countries to allow women to study mathematics and science at advanced academic level, the UK doesnrsquot stack up well compared to the rest of the world. In Europe, Bulgaria, Latvia and Cyprus lead the way with a  per cent female engineering workforce, while India has double the rate of our female engineering graduates at  per cent.Paul Sheeran, Chief Executive of Scottish Engineering, believes the lack of women is hurting the profession ndash and should be tackled as far back as nursery school.ldquoIn the UK, we have an annual shortfall of , engineering graduates and technicians to fill roles, but we are missing out on some of the smartest people on the planet because they happen to be female. Itrsquos holding our industry back.

title: boost-scottish-tourism-chinese-flash-spending-power
story: Now the falling pound and an upswing in Chinese spending power is set to provide a much-needed boost for the country.Chinarsquos buoyant economy and a new wanderlust spirit to explore the world and a fall in the value of sterling are said to be providing perfect conditions for a further tourism boom.One Edinburgh based tour company is reporting a massive  per cent leap in Chinese visitors this summer compared to last. Tourists from China tend to travel from August to October.According to analysts from mobile payments  JGOO, the shting financial landscape could see Chinese visitorsrsquo spending power soar by a staggering %sterling hits parity against the US dollar and the yuan holds its value.Translated into spending here, it could boost the average spend during a UK holiday by a Chinese visitor by pound, to pound. Although % of Chinese touristsrsquo money is spent in London, Scotland is said to take a .% share of overall spending.The unexpected benefit of a falling pound comes in the wake of an almost six-fold increase in Chinese visitors to Scotland since . According to the International Passenger Survey, , Chinese visitors toured Scotland last year, spending a total of pound. million.But it is thought those figures may be conservative, with Edinburgh Castle reporting , visitors from China between March  and April .Figures for this year are expected to show a further jump reflecting the launch of direct flights between Edinburgh and Beijing last summer, while VisitBritain has predicted Chinese visitors to the UK are expected to soar by almost % over the next five years.According to Richard Morecroft, Director and Co-Founder of JGOO, which provides Western retailers access to the Chinese market through WeChat Pay and Alipay, a sliding pound sparked by Brexit fears could spark extra tourists and lead to a wave of fresh trade as Chinese customers seek to spend high with UK retailers.ldquoIfdoes fall, this will no doubt have a negative impact on many parts of the UK economy.
